Title: How pollution is disrupting lives in Gurgaon
Body:
Gurgaon: Our lifespans are shrinking every year, and there's evidence to back up that claim.In a recent study on the air quality life index by the Energy Policy Institute at the University of Chicago, it was shown that Indians living in the plains face having seven years lopped off their life expectancy. In Gurgaon, often ranked the most polluted city in the nation, that statistic assumes more menacing proportions.For many in Gurgaon, life has been disrupted by a smog that lingers like an overlong nightmare. It's a state of affairs for which the authorities, twiddling their thumbs while citizens daily breathe in a cocktail of toxins, are wholly culpable. "Crores of people are affected by this and still everyone is silent - are we waiting for the Great NCR Smog?"
asked Raveesh Shrivastava, who recently became a father.Poignantly, Raveesh can't set eyes on his little one because of the thick haze that hangs ominously, and seemingly perpetually, over his hometown, leaving him and everyone else deprived of the sun's life-giving warmth. "Unfortunately, I never thought I will have to leave him because of this pollution; both my wife and baby are vulnerable. When I am myself waking up sneezing and coughing, how can I get the mother and child back?"For a week, Aadish Pal, who lives in Sector 50, has been suffering from an eye infection. "I was told by the doctor that itching of eyes is a common symptom which people in the city have been complaining about. My wife is also suffering from cold because of infection from the air we inhale," he told TOI.Pooja Aggarwal, a Faridabad resident who commutes to Gurgaon for work, likened the 10-minute wait for her shuttle outside office to being trapped in a gas chamber. "Normally, the smog clears and pollution levels come down a week after Diwali. But, this time it's persisting as if to haunt us, and remind us how we have created this Frankenstein's monster," she said, describing a scene straight out of a 19th-century Gothic novel."As such, breathing is difficult... the situation is really scary these days," continued Aggarwal, echoing the fears of many in the Millennium City. And if you're a pedestrian, it's an even harder life. For, you risk being exposed to traffic fumes and the suffocating smog. "I don't know what to complain about - the inability to breathe or (inability) to see roads while crossing them," remarked Rupesh Singh, a Delhi resident who works in an IT firm in Gurgaon.So dire is the situation that many, especially the elderly, feel it would be better if they left Gurgaon for good, only because they have been denied their basic right of clean air. "This is the fourth consecutive year that we are witnessing polluted air, and, at the age of 70, it is difficult to process air which is not suitable to breathe. I am unable to take morning and evening walks," lamented Praveen Agarwal, a resident of Sector 46.This city, he adds despondently, is no longer liveable. "We have been advised by doctors not to step out of our homes as the bad air will complicate our health issues."Predictably, city hospitals have been logging more visits from people complaining of breathing problems. According to Dr Piyush Goel, senior pulmonologist at Columbia Asia, there has been a 30% increase in respiratory cases, with new cases coming in every day. "There has also been an increase in health conditions such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (or, COPD)," he revealed.Dr Arunesh Kumar - senior pulmonologist, and head of department, Chest Institute and Respiratory Medicine, Paras Hospital, Gurgaon - pointed to a rise of 30% in respiratory disorders in the past week, and an increase of 20% in new cases in the last couple of days alone. "The air now contains highly toxic heavy metals such as lead, copper, zinc, manganese, sodium, potassium, etc. Such presence of metals in the air can trigger an asthma attack in a patient, causing severe headaches and respiratory problems," he explained.More troublingly, Dr Goel reveals, overexposure to pollution can result in lung cancer. And even the foetus in a mother's womb, he adds, is not safe from air heavy with pollutants. This is, by any standards, a health emergency, but you wouldn't know it from the response (or lack thereof) from those in power, a response that's as invisible as the particulate matter that penetrates our noses, eyes and mouths.Kids, too, can't escape the effects of bad air. "I don't go out at all and staying indoors is not fun," rues Brinda Aggarwal, a Class IX student. She's not unlike other Gurgaon schoolchildren, silently cursing the pollution for keeping them inside. Meanwhile, Brinda's brother Rohan is more concerned about his studies than his health.Whether working professionals or schoolgoing children, housewives or senior citizens, the majority of Gurugrammers is struggling to make it through each day without fretting over their physical wellbeing. "We are worried about our health as we do not see any improvement in the condition, for the air quality is still in severe category," bemoans Pal. But, unlike the Londoners of 1952, they can't see a way out of this gloom. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: November 15, 2019

Title: Goel flouts rule in protest, AAP says unfortunate
Body:
New Delhi: On Day 1, the road-rationing scheme allowed only even-numbered private cars on Delhi's roads. However, Delhi BJP leader and Rajya Sabha MP Vijay Goel travelled in his odd-numbered car to protest against the "gimmick". "This scheme is just a gimmick. The AAP government itself says the pollution is due to stubble burning, then how does the scheme help?"
Goel asked while starting from Chandni Chowk. He later stopped at the roundabout near Le Meridian Hotel in central Delhi and volunteered to get penalised.Calling Goel's move "unfortunate", AAP said BJP leaders were sending a message to people to not follow Delhi government's efforts to curb air pollution. Transport minister Kailash Gahlot also met Goel at his residence with a bouquet of flowers to request him "to co-operate with the people of Delhi in the coming days".The last digit of Goel's SUV was 7 and he had got anti-government and anti-scheme slogans pasted all over it. A former Delhi BJP chief, Goel was accompanied by the party's Delhi in-charge, Shyam Jaju, West Delhi MP Parvesh Saheb Singh Verma and others. Goel was the most vocal BJP leader against the scheme during its first and second editions too. "I am doing this as a symbolic protest against the Kejriwal government's failure to do anything in five years to curb pollution in Delhi. It is now staging a drama and an election stunt in view of the coming assembly polls," Goel said. Speaking to Gahlot in front of the media, Goel said if the AAP government was serious, it should have called a meeting of all seven Delhi MPs. He also questioned its timing. All Delhi MPs are from BJP. Gahlot said, If 50% cars do not ply, at least some amount of pollution will reduce." The government found an unlikely supporter in Delhi Congress' Ajay Maken. "Vijay Goel MP-A LawMaker! Is deliberately driving an odd-number car on an even-numbered day! I've been (the) most vocal critic of Kejriwal - But I will never contribute to air pollution as a way of protest!" Maken tweeted. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Title: Haryana to cancel firearm licences of farmers who burnt crop residue
Body:
CHANDIGARH: In a deterrent measure to stop farmers in Haryana from burning stubble, which has become one of the reasons for massive air pollution, the state government has initiated the process to cancel their arms' licences.A large number of notices have been issued by the deputy commissioners of paddy sowing belts in the state to the farmers who were found to be involved in burning crop residue. Maximum of such notices have been issued in Sirsa and Fatehabad, districts with high number of arms' licences. The notices have been issued by the DCs, who also act as district magistrates, on receiving recommendations from the superintendents of police (SPs) of the area.The notices are issued to farmers, who are booked under Section 188 (disobedience to order duly promulgated by public servant) of IPC for burning stubble despite ban by the administration. 
On verification, if the police finds if the farmer who burnt stubble has been issued arms' licence, a recommendation is made by the SP concerned to the DC for cancellation of that licence with the remarks that keeping of arms licence by such person is "not in public interest".On receiving SP's recommendations, the DC issues a notice under Section 17 (3) of the Arms Act, 1959, beginning the process for cancellation of the licence of farmer concerned. According to the data received from the state agriculture department, nearly 1,500 FIRs have been registered till date in Haryana for burning stubble.Talking to TOI, one of the DCs said the move will be of great help for the administration to pressurise farmers indulging in stubble burning. Getting an arms' licence is not only a difficult task, but is also considered a matter of prestige in the local society. "This would certainly act as deterrent, as people do not want to lose their arms' licences that they had procured for self-defence. Legally also, once FIR is registered against them for defiance of government order, a ground is made for cancellation of licence," DC had informed.When contacted, Keshni Anand Arora, chief secretary Haryana, said the decision to cancel licences have been taken by the DCs at their level to control the situation of stubble burning in the state.Several other serious efforts are also being made by the authorities to stop stubble burning. "It was perhaps because of the stringent steps taken by the authorities, Haryana is able to control the incidents of fires due to stubble burning, when compared with Punjab. Clear directions have been issued, empowering DCs to take all possible steps to curb this menace," Arora said.According to S Narayanan, member secretary, Haryana State Pollution Control Board (HSPCB), till date, nearly 6,296 cases of stubble fire have been reported in the state this season when compare with previous year's 8,750 cases. He also confirmed that number of incidents of fire in Punjab is higher. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Title: Is air pollution also making us depressed? Studies agree
Body:
Unless you have been living under the rock, you must be well aware of the thick envelope of toxic air that has engulfed Delhi-NCR. The residents are waking up to irritated eyes, sore throat and a sensation of choking. The air pollution levels have reached a disturbing three-year high, well into the "severe" range.The dangers of air pollution on human health From respiratory distress to heart, brain and even the health of the expectant mothers, these unusually high levels of particulates in the air are known to cause several acute and chronic medical conditions. 
However, in addition to an increased risk of cardiovascular diseases and respiratory symptoms, this dangerous cocktail of air pollutants can damage your mental health as well.The psychological impact of the choking airExposure to high levels of air pollution has been linked with affecting brain development in children and worsen the existing mental health conditions. Yes, the dreaded air pollution seems to damage much more than the visible physiological effects. According to a journal published in the Lippincott Portfolio by Wolters Kluwer, the mental health of the teenagers is more susceptible to the damage caused by airborne particles.The studyTo conduct the research, 144 teenagers were given a social stress test which included a five-minute speech and a math test. Shockingly, after studying the adolescents' heart rate and other bodily responses, it was found that teenagers with a higher autonomic response to stress, also had an increased level of PM 2.5 near their house. While the association between polluted air and greater stressors has not been explained in the study, it re-emphasises the fact that toxic air may also damage neurodevelopment and cognitive function.How air pollution is STRESSING us outIt does not matter which news channel you put on or newspaper you pick up to read, they are flooded with the impact of deadly levels of air pollution. Moreover, the doctors have strongly advised avoiding stepping outside unless absolutely needed. People have also been asked to stop working out outdoors and avoid strenuous exercises which may cause rapid breathing. Short winter days, grey skies and the presence of choking air everywhere are bound to stress anyone out and contribute to a persistent low mood.Can air pollution also plunge you into depressionA report published in the Ochsner Journal points to data from China published in 2018. According to that data, every 1 standard deviation rise in particulate matter over an average PM2.5 concentration increases the likelihood of having mental illness (including depression) by 6.67%. Hence, dirty air is not only suffocating your lungs, but it also impacts the way you think. There is clearly a desperate need to conduct in-depth researches to determine the extent of damage air pollution is doing to our mental health.The bottom lineFor now, instead of panicking over the stuffy air and AQI updates, it is more important to focus on what needs to be done. From carpooling, reducing the number of times you use your car, using public transport, planting more trees to completely avoiding burning trash, there is a lot that can be done on an individual level. Title: HP CM suggests to make pollution treatment plant mandatory for new industries
Body:
SHIMLA: Chief minister Jai Ram Thakur said that it should be made mandatory for all upcoming industrial units to have pollution treatment plant. He said that state pollution control board should also ensure that all the existing common effluent treatment plants should function properly so that water released downstream does not gets polluted. He said that special thrust should be laid on checking pollution in industrial towns like Baddi, Barotiwala, Nalagarh, Parwanoo and Kala Amb.While presiding over the meeting of Himachal Pradesh State Environmental Protection and Pollution Control Board at Shimla on Wednesday, Jai Ram Thakur said that work on improvement in functioning of existing common effluent treatment plant at Baddi, with respect to, connecting the convergence pipes to treat 1.10 MLD waste water from industries falling in river Sirsa catchment must be completed, at the earliest.He said that state government is committed to maintain pristine and salubrious environment in the state and would ensure that existing and new industrial units coming up in the State fulfil all the norms related to pollution control.He said that a proposal for setting up common effluent treatment plant at Kala Amb area in Sirmaur district, would be prepared to provide much relief to the people of area. 
He said that in addition to this, there was a proposal for setting up of solid waste management facility at Kala Amb.Jai Ram Thakur said that apart from water and solid waste pollution, concerted steps should also be taken to curb air pollution. He said that usually it had been felt that kutcha roads in industrial areas with heavy vehicular movement cause air pollution. He said that regular cleaning must be done of road dust and sprinkling of water on kutcha road through tankers.He said that trees should be planted along side roads and pucca pavements must be constructed along the roads. He said that efforts should also be made for developing green belts, gardens and parks in open areas so that people could be benefitted.He also directed the concerned authorities for ensuring proper design and laying of sewerage lines besides ensuring their proper maintenance. Title: Delhi-NCR air pollution: Task force suggests lifting ban on dirty-fuel factories
Body:
NEW DELHI: As air quality improved on Saturday, the CPCB-led Graded Response Action Plan task force recommended lifting the ban on industries operating on coal in Delhi-NCR."Industrial operations such as coal-based industries in Faridabad, Gurugram, Ghaziabad, Noida, Greater Noida, Sonepat and Bahadurgarh, and non-PNG industries in Delhi, which were earlier banned by EPCA, may commence subject to taking adequate control measures and compliance to prescribed environmental norms," the task force stated.Supreme Court had on November 4 banned construction and demolition activities in the region till further orders. "Hot mix plant, ready mix plants and stone crusher shall continue to remain closed," the task force stated on Saturday.As part of pre-emptive steps during the polluted Diwali period, SC-appointed EPCA on suggestions of the task force ordered ban on construction from 6pm to 6am from October 26-30. On October 31, the ban was extended four more hours from 6pm to 10am. 
On November 1, complete ban was announced before the apex court blanket ban.During the meeting on Saturday, officials noted how improvement in AQI was observed, which reached 'very poor' from 'severe' and 'severe plus' categories it was hovering around in the past few days.The state pollution control boards and other implementing agencies have, however, been asked to continue to remain on alert, ensure regular surveillance and take all necessary actions to curb air polluting activities.Earlier, on November 6, the Supreme Court gave Delhi government seven days to fix the 13 spots identified as the most polluted in the city. Title: No more flush & forget, it's time for decentralised faecal sludge mgmt
Body:
Mumbai: While crores of toilets have been built across the country, the question is: After you flush, what happens? The invisible underground activity that has long been associated with shame, caste and untouchability is finally being addressed with some urgency and being translated into government reports and targets."The earlier thought was 'flush and forget' but now the government is trying to change that," says Arumugam Kalimuthu, programme director of the Water and Sanitation Hygiene Institute, a research and advocacy non-profit organisation. "Current sanitation services are not keeping up with the amount of faecal sludge generated in cities, and there are enormous health hazards." 
He refers to the need for a decentralised approach to the sanitation chain-emptying, conveying, treating and, possibly, recycling human waste-which is now being viewed as the best scalable model.Recognising the inadequacy of the sewer line network, the state government recently resolved to build 311 decentralised sewage treatment plants, starting with one in Nagpur. Some 74 plants are already operational in towns. Odisha also has fecal sludge treatment plants in seven cities and recently committed to scale up to 114 urban local bodies.The decentralised approach is based on a local faecal sanitation chain, which separates liquid and solid waste and treats them separately (see graphic). While treated solid waste is used as compost in agriculture, the liquid waste meets water needs. When treated correctly, human waste can be converted into useful byproducts, including fuel, fertiliser and irrigation water. The model is based on a treatment plant set up in Devanahalli, Bengaluru, by Consortium for DEWATS (Decentralised Wastewater Treatment Systems) Dissemination Society in partnership with the local government. The Rs 60-lakh plant can service 35,000 to 40,000 people.Government figures reveal that only 37% of the total 62,000 million litres per day of sewage generated in urban India is treated. Based on lastest census data, 32.7% of urban households are connected to a piped sewer system, whereas 38.2% dispose of wastes into septic tanks and about 7% into pit latrines, underlining the pre-dominance of on-site arrangements. Many septic tanks built by private operators are not properly lined at the bottom, according to the Centre for Science and Environment. Also, even if the outlet from a septic tank is connected to a stormwater drain, it could be a public health hazard as the liquid run-off needs to be channeled into soak pits or other appropriate systems. According to Energy Alternatives India estimates, India produces 1.2 lakh tonnes of faecal sludge a day, and 60% of it is dumped in water bodies or land. This results in water contamination and public health crisis. Experts point out that, like air pollution, the hazards of disorganised toilet management are class-agnostic. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Title: Suggest out-of-the-box ideas to combat pollution: Naidu to scientists
Body:
NAGPUR: Expressing concern over the rising air pollution in many parts of the country, Vice-President M Venkaiah Naidu urged scientists to come up with "out-of-the-box" solutions to combat the crisis.Naidu was speaking at the inaugural function of the two-day 15th international symposium on metal ions and organic pollutants in biology, medicine and environment organized by the National Environment Engineering Research Institute (Neeri) here on Wednesday. Naidu also launched Neeri's public outreach programme 'Jagruti-Ek Samaj, Ek Lakshya' which aims at creating a knowledge base of all rivers and lakes with public participation. Stressing that environmental pollution and deterioration of ambient air quality are one of the foremost challenges currently facing the country, Naidu said that environment degradation will have a direct impact on the development of the nation. Referring to the World Economic Forum findings, Naidu stated that the cost of environmental degradation in India was estimated to be Rs 3.75 trillion a year. 
He also cited the latest Centre for Science and Environment's State of India's Environment (SoE) report which highlighted that air pollution was responsible for 12.5% of deaths in India. "The air quality index measurements in most of the major cities constantly register air qualities that are 'poor' or 'severe'. Air Quality in Delhi on Wednesday fell in the category of 'hazardous' with particulate matter (PM) 10 and 2.5 soaring high. The numbers are indeed alarming and are a cause for great concern," said Naidu.On the National Clean Air Programme (NCAP), he added, "The programme will be a midterm, five-year action plan with 2019 as the first implementing year. The main aim of the programme would be 20-30% reduction of PM2.5 and PM10 concentration by 2024. Also, the metal ions and organic pollutants present in the air we breathe are extremely deleterious to health."Suggesting another measure to reduce emissions, the vice president stressed the need to promote renewable sources of energy. He also advised regular cleaning, preservation, and maintenance of water bodies, which are "turning toxic" with increased urbanization. "The CSE Report also estimates that 86 water bodies in the country are critically polluted, with both surface and groundwater being under severe stress. Groundwater is also facing over exploitation, there has been an unsustainable increase in the number of deep tube wells that has gone up by 80% between 2006-07 and 2013-14," said Naidu. Adding that around 70% of surface water in India is unfit for consumption, Naidu said, "The quantity and type of metal ions present in water determine the possible health and environmental hazards. Detection and removal of contamination from water in a cost-effective manner must be our priority."Terming cancer as a "burden on India" which has more than doubled over the last 26 years, the Vice-President stated that a number of studies have linked cancer to several environmental factors including pollution and radiation. "The second-most common cause of death in India after cardiovascular disease must receive attention from both doctors and policymakers.The key to curing cancer is early detection, in which imaging plays a crucial part. We must also constantly innovate and create new, less invasive treatment protocols for cancer that are affordable and accessible," he said, urging scientists to translate research and development in local languages to benefit the people. In his address, Neeri director Rakesh Kumar said that though the environmental standards so far formulated are linked with health, medical professionals and environmental scientists do not come together to discuss environment and health issues. "Neeri has made this attempt through this symposium," he added. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Title: B'lureans breathe in cleaner air on rainy days
Body:
Bengaluru: At a time when Delhiites continue to battle poor air quality, Bengalureans are comparatively breathing easy despite the approaching winter. Thanks to bouts of rain.Air Quality Index (AQI) for the city on an average remains satisfactory (around 80) in comparison to the national capital where it's very poor (350 and above). In fact, Bengaluru's air quality has been better compared than that of other cities like Chennai, Hyderabad and Mumbai, for the past few days.Though Bengaluru doesn't have to deal with problems like stubble burning, vehicular emissions do contribute heavily to air quality, which deteriorates before and during winter. Experts say intermittent rain in the past few weeks has helped Bengaluru maintain better air quality as showers arrest the impact of dust and other pollutants to a large extent. 
Interestingly, during three rain-free days early this week, the air quality did worsen a bit. Air quality is considered good when the AQI is below 50 and satisfactory when it's within 100. On Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday (which got no rain), it hovered around 150.Lokeshwari H, scientific officer with Karnataka State Pollution Control Board (KSPCB), said air quality in Bengaluru is comparatively better these days with AQI staying in the satisfactory zone. "Usually, it starts getting poorer during the end of October and November, and pollution levels peak in December, January and February," she added.Nagappa B, an air quality expert and former senior scientific officer with KSPCB, said reduction in air pollution when it rains is known as wet precipitation. "Suspended particulate matter and other harmful chemicals in the air get dissolved, resulting in better ambient air quality whenever it rains. In the absence of precipitation, pollutants get accumulated," he explained.A senior official with KSPCB said Bengaluru received copious rain due to the extended monsoon and impact of cyclones. "Even now, the city is witnessing rain because of the onset of northeast monsoon. However, the air quality may not remain good for long. As rain recedes and winter sets in, Bengaluru will also choke as it does every winter," he added.Box: B'luru and air pollutionAQI: Good (0-50), Satisfactory (51-100), Moderate (101-200), Poor (201-300), Very Poor (301-400), Severe (401-500)AQI in Bengaluru over past few days: Nov 7 (155), Nov 6 (154), Nov 5 (130), Nov 4 (81), Nov 3 (71), Nov 2 (68), Nov 1 (65), Oct 31 (52), Oct 30 (64), Oct 29 (80)Source: KSPCB, CPCB For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Title: Don't scrap double-decker buses, activists urge Maharashtra CM Uddhav Thackeray
Body:
MUMBAI: Transport experts on Sunday demanded that the 72 double-decker buses which are to be scrapped should be replaced with "double deckers only", and suggested that the fleet could be maintained at 100 twin-deck buses. TOI recently wrote about BEST's plan to scrap 72 double-deckers and replace them with single-decker buses, primarily due to "huge operational costs". A final call on the replacement will be taken soon. The double-decker buses completed 82 years of service in Mumbai on Sunday.Commuter rights activists Irfan Machiwala and Mustaq Ansari wrote a petition to CM Uddhav Thackeray, stating that "these iconic buses should be visible on road". The petition also mentioned: "BEST should ignore losses and preserve the buses for their heritage value. 
Many prefer the front seats of the upper deck as you can simply enjoy the cool breeze. It is a refreshing experience. More double-decker buses should be purchased."A member of the Mumbai Mobility Forum, A V Shenoy, said, "We should not completely phase out double-deckers, but maintain at least 100 of them which can be operated in areas where there is not much of a traffic issue."Transport expert Nikhil Desai said double-deckers were a pride of Mumbai. "They should continue to operate in areas such as Marine Drive, near Gateway and other tourist spots," he said. Vidyadhar Date of Aamchi Mumbai, Aamchi BEST said if London can have several double-deckers, why can't Mumbai. "It's not just about transport, it's a heritage of the city which needs to be preserved," he suggested.Machiwala added, "These buses are able to provide a high seating capacity in a limited space. They occupy less road and carry more passengers. Air pollution will reduce when more double-deckers are introduced."Ansari said, "BEST double-deckers were launched to cope with the increasing number of commuters in buses and were modelled along the lines of London's red double-decker buses." Title: Air quality suffers for sixth straight day
Body:
Lucknow: The steady rise in air pollution levels continued for the sixth consecutive day in the city on Saturday with the increase in the density of fog and chill.The Air Quality Index (AQI) on Saturday touched 340, an increase of 19 units over Friday's 321. The AQI reading on December 22 was 349, which dropped to 278 on December 23. Thereafter, the AQI started rising again December 24 onwards, increasing by 20 units on an average. Experts said that it may touch the 401-mark by December 31, sending the city into the 'very poor' category.The AQI is average of PM 2.5 and PM 10 concentration in the air over a period of 24 hours. 
The reading is said to be 'good' if the value is between 0-50, 'poor' if it's between 201 and 300, 'very poor if it's between 301 and 400 and 'severe' if it's above 400. The AQI had dropped on December 23 because of strong easterly winds. However, the wind pattern changed and cold winds from snow-fed mountains in Himachal Pradesh started lashing the city. They led to the formation of fog, which combined with pollutants in the air to form smog."This smog enveloping the city is responsible for the rise in air pollution," said Dhruvsen Singh, director of Lucknow University's weather and pollution monitoring cell. "The situation is likely to aggravate till December 31 as weather conditions are expected to remain conducive for smog, he added. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: December 29, 2019
Ally: Dhruvsen Singh director of Lucknow University's weather and pollution monitoring cell

Title: Rain betters city's air quality index from poor to satisfactory
Body:
Bhopal: Rain seems to have the "magic" formula to control air pollution. Moderate rain in Bhopal on Tuesday evening didn't bring the temperature down as much as the air quality index (AQI). According to Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB) data, the AQI, which stood at 235 on Tuesday, showing "poor" air quality in the city, dropped to 78, showing air quality to be "satisfactory".Small and bigger particulate matter (PM-2.5 and PM-10), which are the major sources of air pollution in Bhopal, came down to 72 and 78 from 235 and 173 respectively. On Monday, the air in Bhopal was all the more polluted with an AQI of 275, presence of PM-2.5 at 275 and PM-10 at 221.What does the rain do to improve air quality?Environmentalist, Subhash C Pandey, said: "In scientific terms, the process is called precipitation. 
As it rains, dust, hazardous particles and gases settled down on the surface of the earth and the air in the atmosphere gets cleaner. It is like "dirt" spread in the atmosphere settling down. This is the reason why in European countries and coastal areas, pollution is not so much a problem. Because in every two-three days, there is rain in these areas and the air is cleaned. By the time pollutants build up again, it rains again."But, it is not rainy season anymore. Tuesday's rain was a one-off occasion. It's winter, a season when air pollution reaches its peak as the air becomes heavy and does not go up in the atmosphere. "Smog" in Delhi is the best example of this phenomenon.Barring Wednesday, when the AQI dropped significantly according to the CPCB data, the AQI throughout the month of December has been "alarmingly" high.While CPCB records AQI at T T Nagar, the M P Pollution Control Board (MPPCB) records it at six points in the city -- two in residential areas, one industrial and three commercial areas.While CPCB figures are available real time, the MPPCB figures are not available so promptly. MPPCB figures for six points, where it records AQI, is thus available till December 10 and that, too, not on a day-to-day basis.The six points, where the MPPCB records AQI, include Paryawas Bhawan (residential), civil hospital, Bairagarh (commercial), CETP Govindpura (industrial), Kolar police station (residential), Hamidia Road (commercial) and Barkatullah University (BU), Hoshangabad Road.MPPCB's AQI figures show Kolar to be the worst place in terms of air pollution with the AQI touching 301 on December 10, which is in "very poor" category. Govindpura, despite being an industrial area, has air pollution in check with AQI in "poor" category only twice in four days, when the data was recorded.While it is no surprise that Hamidia Road, perhaps the most crowded and congested market place in Bhopal, is in the "poor" category, according to the AQI, Bairagarh and Hoshangabad road (both commercial areas with heavy traffic, dust and crowded streets) having AQI quite similar to Paryawas Bhawan in Arera Hills (in moderate category) are also in the same category.The chief chemist at the MPPCB regional office, Dr Sangeeta Dani, when contacted for comments, said: "Air quality depends on several factors like vehicular traffic, quality of roads, wind flow in that area, surroundings, greenery and open space. Hoshangabad Road has heavy traffic but it has open spaces. Hence, dust and particles kicked up by vehicular traffic don't remain confined there but disperse, therefore reducing the AQI. Hamidia Road, on the other hand, is a closed area and dust or other particles remain stuck there, they don't go away."Subhash C Pandey, however, was not convinced with the explanation. "Their data has always been "erratic". They are never reliable. There always seems to be contrivance to show good air quality. How can Arera Hills have the same AQI as Bairagarh or Hoshangabad Road? Maybe there are open spaces on Hoshangabad Road, but that alone can't ensure good air quality in an area," he said. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Title: Reject CAA, focus on jobs: CM
Body:
New Delhi: Chief minister Arvind Kejriwal on Friday said the central government and the entire country should reject the Citizenship Amendment Act and focus on employment instead. "This is not a Hindu-Muslim issue," Kejriwal said, responding to question at a town hall organised at Maharaja Agrasen College in east Delhi. Commenting on his absence from the protests against CAA and National Register of Citizens in the capital, Kejriwal said he was trying to ensure that there was no violence anywhere and the agitation remained peaceful. 
"My job is to maintain peace in Delhi and ensure its development. I was taking all steps necessary to ensure that there was no violence or police excesses," the CM said. Questioning the necessity for the citizenship law at this juncture, he said: "It says that even Hindus will have to leave the country if they don't have identity documents for themselves and their parents... The economy is down and the unemployment rate is high. Our children don't have jobs and houses. They (Centre) say they will bring in two crore Hindus from Pakistan. Where will they be settled?"At the fourth of the seven planned town halls, Kejriwal presented the five-year report card of his government and said that if AAP was re-elected, the priority of his government would be to clean up the Yamuna, make Delhi the cleanest city of the world and address air pollution. "Cleaning up the Yamuna is our priority for the next five years. The river is polluted by sewer and industrial waste from the city. We have identified and planned a waste-management system. I assure you that, in the next five years, we will clean up the river. I will be the first one to take a dip in the river," Kejriwal said. Asked whether he was confident about AAP winning the election, he said: "AAP will win in Delhi. We are witnessing different voting patterns in the Lok Sabha and assembly polls." Among the audience, Gautam Maya Gupta from Kondli lauded the efforts of Delhi government at improving the living conditions of people in unauthorised colonies. "We have got roads, sewer pipelines, water and power connectivity in the last five years," she said. Manvi, a Class XII student from School of Excellence in Khichripur, said government schools' infrastructure and facilities were now at the same level as their private counterparts. Kejriwal also highlighted the improvement in the performance of students from government schools in board examinations. An emotional Meenakshi shared her experience of getting a compensation of Rs 1 crore when her policeman husband died in line of duty in 2017. Kejriwal said that, earlier, only a sewing machine was given as compensation to such widows, but now AAP government was not only giving them a compensation of Rs 1 crore but also the title of a martyr. Title: 2 more air monitoring stations to become functional today
Body:
PATNA: The Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB) has installed two more continuous ambient air quality monitoring stations at Patna and Hajipur, which would be operational from Monday (January 13). A proposal in this regard has been sent to the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB).The new stations will be linked to the national grid soon, an official at the board said.The new stations have been set up at DRM office in Khagaul and government office in Hajipur town area. One more air monitoring station will be operational by this month at Government Boy's High School in Patna City. The installation work is underway.The stations would provide information regarding the ambient air quality along with individual readings of seven parameters, including PM 2.5 (particulate matters less than 2.5 microns), PM 10 (particulate matters less than 10 microns), Nitrogen Dioxide (NO2), Carbon Monoxide (CO), Sulfur Dioxide (SO2), Ozone and Ammonia (NH3). It will also show the temperature, humidity, wind speed and other climatic conditions of the day.The new air monitoring boards are procured from a US-based company, which cost around Rs1.15 crore each.The state capital presently has four monitoring stations at Eco Park, Planetarium, Birla Institute of Technology-Mesra at Patna and SK Memorial Hall.BSPCB chairman Ashok Ghosh told this newspaper that the installation work of monitoring stations have been done and it will be soon connected with the CPCB server. 
"The city's overall air quality index (AQI) would now be calculated on inputs from five monitoring stations. It will give the clear picture of air pollution in the city," he said."At least 10 monitoring stations are needed in a city like Patna to get a broader scenario with regard to air pollution. With four stations in city, we have covered only 70% area of the city," he added.Ghosh said two more stations have been proposed at Kankarbagh and Digha.Besides Patna and Hajipur, a monitoring station each will also come up at Bhagalpur, Darbhanga, Gaya and Muzaffarpur by December-end. The state government is also planning to set up 42 monitoring stations in different cities of Bihar.The BSPCB, in association with other organizations that works for environment, had prepared a comprehensive action plan. It also conducted a source appointment study to help it prepare data to quantify proportion of various elements to the overall level of air pollution in Patna. The source appointment study is now taking place at other two districts, including Gaya and Muzaffarpur. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Hero: Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB)
Ally: Central Pollution Control Board

Title: After rain, temp likely to dip to 7C by Friday
Body:
New Delhi: Rain lashed many parts of the capital on Tuesday and, along with good wind speed, improved the air quality of Delhi to the "poor" category."It rained in the early hours and in the evening again. After the overnight rain, drizzle is expected on Wednesday morning. 
It was a windy day as easterly winds, blowing at 25km per hour with gusty spells of around 30-35km per hour, was witnessed in Delhi," a MeT official said.The India Meteorological Department said that Wednesday onwards, the wind direction would change to northwesterly and chilly winds from the hills would cause the minimum temperature to fall to 7 degrees Celsius by Friday. The minimum temperature on Tuesday was 10.5 degrees Celsius, two notches above normal, and the maximum 22.2, normal for this time of the year."On Wednesday, partly cloudy sky is expected with possibility of very light rain or drizzle in the morning. The maximum and minimum temperatures will be around 21 and 10 Celsius, respectively," IMD stated.According to the Central Pollution Control Board, the air quality index, which was in the "very poor" range - 345 - on Monday, improved to "poor" - 243 - on Tuesday. According to SAFAR, a central forecast agency, it is likely to improve to the "moderate" category by Wednesday morning. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Title: Noisier nights across Bengaluru, and we may well pay a steep price
Body:
BENGALURU: Nights in Bengaluru are no longer quiet. In fact, data of the Karnataka State Pollution Control Board for June-December 2019 show that in some areas, noise levels at night are double the prescribed standard.The area near Wilson Garden, close to Nimhans, is a case in point. It houses one of the 10 continuous noise monitoring stations installed by KSPCB in different parts of the city. Though the area is categorised as a sensitive zone as it has hospitals, the average noise level at night is 75% more than the prescribed limit. 
The figure is more than double during day.The noise levels at night were 97% more the prescribed limit at this station last December, a record of sorts for any area in the city. The movement of interstate buses in the area is a major factor for this dubious record.It's the same with the monitoring station at RVCE, Mysuru Road, another sensitive area as it's home to an educational institution. Here too, vehicular movement on the adjacent highway coupled with ongoing Metro construction work are to blame for the high noise levels.Nights are no longer peaceful in Bengaluru's residential areas either. In Domlur, BTM Layout and Basaveshwaranagar, where the pollution control board monitors noise levels, nights are way too noisier than ever before. Interestingly, increasing noise levels have pushed citizen groups in Indiranagar, Koramangala and a few other areas to seek the court's intervention.The night noise level data for commercial areas like Church Street, Marathahalli and Yeshwantpur are also not a happy story as the figures exceed the prescribed level.H Lokeshwari, chief scientific officer, KSPCB, analysed the worrying development. "It means that vehicular movement, commercial operations, construction activities, etc. that generate noise have increased at night. While this is inevitable in a growing city, one cannot rule out violations like high noise levels in pubs and construction activities. This needs to be fixed," she said.She went on to say, "We're in the process of collating more data on noise pollution hotspots in the city. Once it's done, specific guidelines will be issued to departments concerned to take up necessary interventions."Whitefield quieterInterestingly, data show that noise levels at night are well within the prescribed limits in industrial areas like Whitefield and Peenya. "While it's understandable in Peenya where most industries are shut at night, there are serious doubts about Whitefield data as there's always vehicular movement, etc," said environmentalist Diwakar K.He points out a factor which should be taken into consideration the way noise levels are monitored. "For silent areas like hospitals and educational institutions, the prescribed limits itself is very stringent, around 50 decibels. However, for commercial areas the level is 75 decibels," he said.Traffic cops in line of fireTraffic police are among the most vulnerable to noise pollution as they are continuously exposed to vehicular honking.A senior traffic officer said noise pollution is impossible to control unless the government comes up with strong policies."Round-the-clock vehicular movement, work on building infrastructure, commercialisation of residential areas, pubs and other establishments not adhering to noise standards are some reasons why noise levels are high even at night," he added."For those with high blood pressure, increasing noise levels are a threat as it increases their heart beat. For police manning traffic, noise levels have become a health concern. To protect ourselves from air pollution, there are masks but there is no device to save them from noise pollution," he added. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: February 10, 2020
Moral Description: Masks can help protect against air pollution

Title: 3K runners gear up to hit the tracks at half marathon
Body:
Kolkata: Around 3,000 people are expected to converge on Red Road on Sunday morning as the Times Half Marathon is flagged off, promoting the importance of a clean environment.Debanshu Dasgupta, director of Straightline, which will curate the event, said the response have been great. "Over 2,500 entries have already registered and we expect another 1,000 people to join the event." Participants can register on www.timesmarathonkolkata.com. Echoing Dasgupta, Prasanta Saha, the race director, said, "Words about the event have spread wide. 
It is a run for a cause, a run for the City of Joy."Sudhir Ahuja, a sports enthusiast, is looking forward to this event. "I am a regular marathon runner, having completed over 20 half marathons and two full marathons across India," he said. Equally excited is model and a trained mountaineer, Madhabilata Mitra. "Running is the best way to stay fit, calm and focused," she said, adding she tries to motivate others to participate in marathons. Samir Agarwal, an investment banker by profession, took up running seriously around four years ago. Since then, he has taken part in a number of 10km marathons and about a dozen half marathons. He aims to run a full marathon in future.Rana Dasgupta, CEO, Apollo Gleneagles Hospitals in Kolkata, said, "This run also stands for something else that is extremely topical in these times: the message that we should do our best to keep the city air clean. We are all aware of the poor air quality index (AQI) in Kolkata and most other urban areas of India. Air pollution around the world is poor but we have to start addressing the issue somewhere. Let us all pledge to do our own bit and not contribute to the rising pollution. We can do this by performing simple tasks, like ensuring our vehicles confirm to the latest emission norms, avoiding bio-mass burning and making sure we do not add anything that would be harmful to the environment."Public relations and communication consultant Swati Poddar, a fitness enthusiast, is all geared up for the Sunday event, which will have three categories of 3km, 10km and 21km runs. "I have been running for six years now. I got a chance to test my own limits," she said.Abhishek Lodha has an advice for people who are yet to decide on whether to participate or not. "To realize your true potential, you have to first find your limits and then muster the courage to go past them," he said. Another enthusiastic participant is Bharat Bagla, a financial planner. Bagla started running five years ago and has participated in over 50 events in different formats both in India and abroad. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Hero: Apollo Gleneagles Hospitals CEO Rana Dasgupta

Title: Amid coronavirus scare, Kolkata begins to heal its air and water quality
Body:
Deserted roads, vacant offices, malls sans customers and anxious residents cooped up in their homes -the past few days have taken a toll on human activities around the world, thanks to the coronavirus pandemic. While we are flooded with upsetting news coming in from all quarters, slowly but surely a highly positive environmental revolution of sorts is taking place in Kolkata. The city, as it seems, is beginning to heal, what with significantly lower pollution levels, cleaner water bodies and rare birds and butterflies making a comeback.Air is cleanerIn November last year, Kolkata's air was fouler than Delhi's, with theaverage air quality index (AQI) going well past the 400-mark at Ballygunge. It prompted health experts to advise restrictions on outdoor activities,particularly morning walks. 
Currently, the city's average AQI is between 70 and 110. "These figures indicate pure bliss. While discussing air pollution, we mostly talk about particles in the air that cause all types of physical illness. With lesser traffic and human activities, the suspended air particles aresignificantly lower in the atmosphere now," said Kalyan Rudra, chairman of West Bengal Pollution Control Board (WBPCB). Similar readings were recorded on Holi due to a traffic slowdown.The skies are getting clearLower amount of suspended particles in the air has led to better visibility too. This is giving photographers and stargazers a much clearer view of Kolkata's skyline and night sky. Kaustuv Chowdhury, secretary general of Kolkata Astronomy Centre, said, "Though we have suspended all meets keeping in mind the coronavirus threat, all our members are stargazing from their respective homes. The stars are much brighter due to the clear sky. Justyesterday, I noticed Venus looking even brighter than usual."Rare birds fly back to the cityLower pollution levels are attracting more birds to the city, including rare ones. According to Swarup Saha, a bird watcher, birds are sensitive to pollution and there have been several sightings of rare birds in Rabindra Sarobar in the last 10 days, much more than compared to recent years. "Large hawk-cuckoo, blue throated blue flycatcher and ultramarine flycatcher are among the most interesting birds spotted recently. This is probably the first time a large hawk-cuckoo has been spotted in Kolkata," said Swarup.Ornithologist Sumit Sen said one of the reasons for the increase in bird sightings is the reduced numbers of cars as well as humans on the streets. "Thanks to lower sound pollution, birds are now coming down on the ground to find food. This has increased the feeding hours for them," he added.Water is cleanerNot just air, the city's water bodies are looking cleaner too. With lesser industrial waste and human activities, there's been a possible reduction in pollutants going into the Hooghly. According to Kalyan, a monthly water test is conducted by WBPCB and the board will be able to reveal the actual data only after testing the Hooghly water next month. However, Bapi Halder, a fisherman and secretary of a south Bengal-based fisherman association, said they have noticed about 5% to 10% increase in the number of fish in the Hooghly. "Many are now sceptical about fishing due to the coronavirus scare. That is helping the fish population grow, especially the small ones. Besides, the water purity has improved with all the big trawlers and boats gone," he said. More butterfliesInsects, known to be highly intolerant to pollution, are also finding their way back to the city. Somenath Pal Das, who specialises in butterfly gardens and breeding butterflies, said the number of butterflies in his garden has multiplied in the last one week. "Though I haven't spotted any rare species yet, the numbers are significantly higher than what I saw even two weeks back," he said. Species like common mormon, common lime, common palmfly and common rose are being sighted commonly now. "Declining pollution levels is the most prominent reason for this. Besides, with fewer vehicles on streets, insects are much more confident to come out of their hidings since collision with high-speed cars is one of the biggest reasons for butterfly deaths," he added.Around the world#In New York, carbon monoxide, mainly from cars, reduced by nearly 50% compared to last year#China's greenhouse gas emissions over the month of February are as much as a quarter below normal levels#A near shutdown of cruise and cargo-ship traffic around Venice has resulted in fish returning to the Venice lagoon and canals for the first time indecades For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: March 22, 2020
Hero: coronavirus pandemic
Moral Description: Coronavirus lockdown led to the environment healing

Title: Evoke: Good opportunity to mitigate climate change
Body:
On Earth Day, Times Evoke begins Evoke Inspire, a unique forum for young readers to express their ideas on the environment and global existential issues.Writing for Evoke Inspire, Siddhant Nigam Sinha, a student at Philips Academy Andover, and founder of the SUN Foundation, discusses steps towards a more sustainable world.In these trying times, our news feeds are overwhelmed by reports from around the world of the huge costs of Covid-19. We hear of hospitals inundated with patients, health workers facing enormous strain, individuals battling extreme circumstances. In the midst of this, however, one ray of hope has emerged - global greenhouse gas emissions have declined and air and water quality has improved in multiple places. In India, for instance, a decline in factory production, air traffic and construction activity have together reduced pollution, leading to noticeably cleaner skies. Astonishingly, the Himalayas were recently visible from Jalandhar, a city hundreds of kilometres away, while numerous reports indicate how rivers like the Ganga and Yamuna are much cleaner today.
Read other stories of Times EvokeHowever, global carbon emissions have seen this decline only due to the current pandemic. In China, as people stayed home and factories contracted output, emissions dropped reportedly by 25%, which translates to around 200 million metric tonnes of carbon dioxide. Some forecasts similarly suggest that European emissions this year could also be nearly 400 million tonnes less than last year.However, seemingly positive though they are, these changes are in no way sustainable as they have come not due to planned actions but on the back of a global crisis, causing unprecedented economic disruption. Last month, as economic activity contracted, a record 10 million Americans reportedly filed for unemployment benefits. In rural and urban India, a large number of business owners and workers face sharply reduced sources of income while economists predict the damage caused by the corona virus could take economies years to recover from. Climate positives that are an outcome of such emergencies, and enormous human distress, are clearly not sustainable.Yet, this moment offers us a chance, of thinking of ways to save our world from the impacts of climate change in the near future. A silver lining today is that many people around the world are finally turning to science and facts, rather than opinions or stands, for information on the corona virus. This presents an opportunity to orient more people towards learning and trusting the science on climate change as well, and thinking of innovative solutions and preventative measures, based on such science.To stand a chance against climate change, we need to implement sustainable and planned structural changes. Importantly, we must reduce our reliance on coal, a major contributor to global carbon emissions. In addition, we must transition to environmentally-friendly energy sources, such as solar power or wind energy. Combating climate change also requires multilateral action as emissions from any country have a global impact. Once this crisis passes, restoring economic health will be vital for all the nations of the world. But this moment gives us all a chance to think of new and better methods to reorganise our economies, in a way that cleaner air and less polluted rivers do not become a thing of memory, but are a lasting positive from this experience. The youth of today must inherit a world where forethought, planning and global cooperation can save us from yet another catastrophe. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Hero: Covid-19
Villain: factory production, air traffic, construction activity, coal
Moral Description: calls to transition to renewable energy sources

Title: First study of air pollutants: Chandigarh finds 7 keen firms
Body:
CHANDIGARH: Seven companies are interested in doing the city's first source appointment study of the proportion of pollutants in the air. After the lockdown, the administration will invite them for discussion.The UT floated the expression of interest (EoI) with the approval of administrator V P Singh Badnore. Chandigarh Pollution Control Committee (CPCC) member secretary T C Nautiyal confirmed the number of bidders who say they can identify the main factors behind air pollution in the city. 
The study will use Rs 80 lakh out of Rs 10 crore given to the city under National Clean Air Programme (NCAP).In 2017, the Union environment ministry had decided to use Rs-5-crore-worth Swiss device for the study in four cities. The Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Kanpur, had procured these machines and one of those was proposed to be installed in Chandigarh. In 2018, the administration rejected the proposal because of high cost but, by then, it had floated the expression of interest, seeking partners for the study.Recently, the administration had also filed with the Union government its action plan to control air pollution in Chandigarh. The UT cited its campaign against polluting vehicles and presented a blueprint of work to widen the roads. The design included synchronization of traffic signals, greening of open areas, introducing tertiary-water-fed fountains at major intersections, promoting battery-operated vehicles, building green buffers along traffic corridors, and introducing an intelligent traffic management system.The UT submitted that a 60% increase in vehicle count over 10 years (with no change in the length of roads) had fouled the city's ambient air. Cars alone have increased by more than 100% in this period, while the city has 48% more two-wheelers. Vehicular density has caused congestion, which has led to air pollution, to which construction and demolition waste, dust, stubble burning, pollen due to greenery, temperature effect, and industrial surroundings have also contributed.The government aims at cutting pollution level by 35% in the next three years and 50% by the next five. Chandigarh is on the list of 100 targeted cities that have a high proportion of nitrogen dioxide, besides particulate matters 2.5 and 10. The air-quality study will look at particulate matter, ground-level ozone, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen dioxide, and carbon monoxide (CO) among other factors. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Title: PCB gives industries license relaxations
Body:
INDORE: Madhya Pradesh Pollution Control Board has relaxed the three months intimation period for auto-renewal of licenses for orange and green category industries.Water and air consents to operate for green and orange category industries shall be auto-renewed for 5 years and 1 year respectively on the basis of a self-declaration form without the need for a three-month intimation period and physical inspection, said Madhya Pradesh Pollution Control Board.Until last year, industries had to inform the board three months in advance for auto-renewal, and this facility was available for alternate renewals with mandatory inspection for license renewal after a year of auto-renewal.Madhya Pradesh Pollution Control Board Indore regional officer RK Gupta said, "Industries of the state have received relaxation from three months intimation for auto-renewal. This year licenses for all orange and green category industries will get auto renewed even if they had availed this facility a year ago. This is done to facilitate industries struggling in tough Covid times."Industries will have to upload a self-declaration form on the board portal stating that air and water pollution levels are under control and details on expansion, products and others.Industries' associations were demanding government to auto-renew licenses from every department amid the outbreak of pandemic. 
They claim small and micro scale industries will be benefited immensely through this relaxation.An industrialist from Indore Ashok Badjatiya said, "If the industry is clean and following all laid norms, it's their right to get their licenses auto-renewed. Just talking about ease of business will not help but eased measures should be implemented to aid industries growth."Industry players said the requirement of documents for renewal of licenses should also be curtailed to avoid delay and ease the process of licensing. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Hero: Madhya Pradesh Pollution Control Board
Moral Description: Licenses required for indeustries to operate

Title: City's air action plan lacks sources of pollution: Analysis
Body:
Nagpur: The city's clean air action plan does not contain information on the sources of air pollution and also lacks a legal mandate for implementation.This was revealed in the latest independent analysis released on Tuesday by the Council on Energy, Environment and Water (CEEW) and Urban Emissions. Under the National Clean Air Programme (NCAP), the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), which is a statutory body of the Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change (MoEFCC), had identified over 100 polluted cities where the prescribed standards for ambient air quality are violated.The city's plan, which has been approved by CPCB subject to some compliances, revealed that post 2006, citizens have been breathing toxic air, with the deadliest pollutant Respirable Suspended Particulate Matter (RSPM) surpassing the national permissible limit.According to the analysis, only 20% of the interventions mentioned in the city's plan call for on-ground pollution control measures. "Over 80% of the actions mentioned in the plan involve overseeing, planning, proposing, preparing, investigating, identifying, ensuring, banning, initiating, launching, planning, restricting and promoting. 
Also, 38% of Nagpur's action strategies are directed at the transport sector and 20% target industries," the analysis stated.During the lockdown, the only real-time monitoring station in the city reported a 30% decline in PM2.5 concentrations. "However, to tackle air pollution in the city in the long-term, a single monitoring station for a city with over 2 million population is insufficient. The Maharashtra Pollution Control Board (MPCB) and the Nagpur Municipal Corporation must collectively prioritize the setting up of more monitoring stations and creating trackable indicators to oversee the progress of implementation of this plan," said Tanushree Ganguly, a researcher at CEEW and a co-author of the study.The analysis also finds that the city's plan lists 66 measures across 17 different agencies. While the MPCB is responsible for only 20% of all actions, the urban local bodies and state transport department share the burden of almost 60% of the actions. Moreover, 34% of actions fall under multiple agencies. Furthermore, the estimates suggest that 21% of the pollution in Nagpur could originate outside city limits. However, the plan does not include any measures to ensure regional coordination," the analysis added.Stating that over 30% of the activities are shared across multiple agencies, Kurinji Selvaraj, a researcher at CEEW and co-author of the study, said, "Fragmentation of accountability is a key impediment. Hence, it is crucial to delineate specific tasks for each action point among participating agencies."As per the study, only five non-attainment cities in the state - Amravati, Aurangabad, Kolhapur, Chandrapur and Mumbai - of the 17 with approved action plans contain information of emission sources. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Hero: Council on Energy, Environment and Water (CEEW) and Urban Emissions, researcher Tanushree Ganguly at CEEW, researcher Kurinji Selvaraj
Ally: National Clean Air Programme (NCAP), the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), Ministry of Environment, Forest and Climate Change (MoEFCC)
Moral Description: Action plan drawn up to combat pollution, but it is lacking, as pointed out by the heroes

Title: Bihar's air quality enters safe zone: BSPCB study
Body:
PATNA: The Covid-19 lockdown may have inconvenienced many, but it has had a positive impact on the overall pollution levels in the state, especially in capital Patna, with air quality entering the 'satisfactory' zone from 'severely polluted' before the lockdown. In a study carried out by the Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB), the impact of the lockdown on the ambient air quality of major cities in the state, including Patna, Muzaffarpur, Gaya, and Hajipur, has been assessed.The study, which is still under progress, collected real-time pollution data in three phases - pre-lockdown Phase 1 (March 12- 21), Phase 2 (March 23-April 19) and Phase 3 (April 20-April 27). It examined the trends of major air pollutants, including particulate matter (PM2.5 and PM2.10) and traced atmospheric gases (NO2, SO2, NH3, Ozone, and CO) before and during the Covid-19 lockdown. BSPCB chairman Ashok Kumar Ghosh said the findings of the study conclude an overall improvement in the air quality of the state since the implementation of the lockdown on March 22."The overall air quality of the state has been improving gradually since the lockdown. 
On March 21, the AQI of Patna was 300, while the concentration of prominent pollutant PM2.5 stood at 300. A month into lockdown, the AQI of Patna dropped down to 76 on April 27 and PM2.5 concentration was 20. It's a very positive development," Ghosh said.According to the national ambient air quality standards, all 11 air monitoring stations across the state have shown air quality index (AQI) of major cities including Patna, Gaya and Muzaffarpur to be either good (0 - 50) or satisfactory (51 - 100) since early April.Attributing the improvement in the air quality to the combined impact of several factors, including low vehicular and industrial emissions, during the lockdown Ghosh said, "The NO2 and SO2 concentration in the Patna is usually high, but with the implementation of restrictions on travel and factories, the levels of these gases were well below the permissible limit."Simultaneous lockdown in the adjoining states and early arrival of monsoons in the state this year also contributed to the improvement in overall air quality and decrease in air pollutants, he added."We don't have much industrial activity in Bihar. A major portion of air pollution in our state was neighborhood pollutants from adjoining states of UP and West Bengal, which were carried by the winds to Bihar. Post lockdown, we noticed a decrease in neighborhood pollution along with the bordering districts of Bihar," he said."Additionally, with the early arrival of southwest monsoon in the state, there was a decrease in air pollutants as most of it settled on the ground due to the rains," he added.According to the AQI bulletin released by the Central Pollution Control Board on Thursday, the AQI of Patna was 41 while that of Gaya and Muzaffarpur was 23 and 62 respectively. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: August 28, 2020
Hero: Covid-19 lockdown, Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB), monsoons
Ally: states of UP and West Bengal
Moral Description: Lockdown and rains made aqi better

Title: Punjab plans to shift brick kilns from coal to CNG
Body:
Chandigarh: Tandrust Punjab Mission director Kahan Singh Pannu has said the state government will explore the possibilities to shift brick kilns from coal to compressed natural gas (CNG) to check air pollution. There are around 2,200 active brick kilns in Punjab.Pannu said the state government had earlier succeeded in shifting most of the active brick kilns to the approved design of high draught zigzag technology, which uses lesser coal as compared to the traditional brick kiln firing system."But, technological advancement in combustion systems has now made it possible to convert even the coal-based brick kilns into CNG-based kilns without much change in their design," he said. Therefore, under the Tandrust Punjab Mission, the state government intends to explore the possibilities of shifting brick kilns from coal to CNG, said Pannu.Brick kilns in Punjab use about 16 lakh tonnes of coal to produce about 1,100 crore bricks every year. 
Although the improved zigzag technology requires lesser coal, still a lot of coal is used for firing the kilns, which is a source of pollution. It was in this context that the Punjab State Council of Science and Technology had been requested to come up with a technology that would replace coal in the brick kilns with CNG, Pannu said, adding that the Punjab Pollution Control Board could also provide necessary assistance in the process.CNG is now amply available in Punjab and a large number of coal-based industrial units are shifting to gas-based units. The shift of brick kilns to CNG would not only help reduce the cost of production of bricks, but also substantially reduce the air pollution load caused by coal-fired kilns, Pannu added. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: August 31, 2020
Hero: state government, Punjab State Council of Science and Technology, Tandrust Punjab Mission, Punjab Pollution Control Board

Title: High-intensity blasts at quarries damaging homes
Body:
Vijayawada: Locals of Donabanda under Nandigama mandal in Krishna district have stopped work at quarry sites and taken to the streets in protest against the use of explosives for quarrying.Locals alleged that high-intensity blasts are damaging their houses and causing pollution and associated health complications. Srinivasa Rao, a resident of Donabanda, said the quarry managements are using ammonium nitrate and other explosives that lead to air pollution while dust from the quarry has given rise to respiratory and digestive problems in locals, he said.Sheik Khaja, another resident, said he had a new house constructed two years ago but every wall has developed deep cracks. "We fear for the safety of our house if the situation continues like this," M Nageswaramma, a local, said her house has also developed cracks at multiple places.Locals alleged that the quarry managements have violated norms by digging rigs with depths of over 100 feet and is stuffing the rigs with high-intensity explosives to mine large quantities of gravel. Despite several representations, official action is yet to be taken, they said, appealing to the mining department to order an inquiry into the issue and take action. The quarries are maintained by two private companies. When contacted, the additional director (AD) of the mining department was not available for comment. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: October 4, 2020
Hero: Locals of Donabanda, Nandigama mandal

Title: Forget 100%, fly-ash utilization of Koradi & Khaparkheda below 30%
Body:
Nagpur: On one hand ministry of environment, forests and climate change (MoEFCC) has allowed use of high ash coal and on the other, the power plants near Nagpur are unable to achieve 100% fly-ash utilization. The fly-ash is being dumped in ash bunds and during heavy rains, it flows into rivers poisoning Nagpur's water supply.Data analysed by the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air (CREA) reveals that the fly-ash utilization of Koradi power plant in 2017-18 was only 13.14%, 2018-19 - 29.12% and first half of 2019-20 - 22.89%. The corresponding figures for Khaparkheda plant are: 2017-18 - 35.56%, 2018-19 - 14.24% and first half of 2019-20 - 20.81%. According to Sunil Dahiya, analyst at CREA, such less utilization of ash at power plants despite multiple timelines for 100% utilization shows how these big polluters are multiple offenders of all rules and regulations, impacting health of citizens. "Recent multiple accidents and ash pond breaches alongside huge water pollution, air pollution, livelihood displacement and stranded asset problems show how this highly fossil fuel-based power generation choice is a detriment to our society at large and how it is a must for us to clean operation of these coal based power plants and shift aggressively to sustainable renewable energy options," he said. 
On August 6, fly-ash from Waregaon ash bund of Khaparkheda plant got discharged into Kanhan river forcing Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) to stop pumping for four hours. At that time Khaparkheda CE Prakash Khandare had stoutly denied that there was any leakage of fly-ash from Waregaon.A few days ago, Pratap Goswami, district organization secretary of Aam Admi Party (AAP), went to Waregaon ash bund and found fly-ash flowing out of it after rains. He clicked photographs and provided them to TOI.A Mahagenco spokesperson claimed that while ash bund overflow the ash did not get discharged into Kanhan river. "Downstream there is a sump and pump house and the fly-ash laden water was pumped back into the bund," he told TOI.Goswami disputes this fact. "Fly-ash may not have got discharged on that particular day but city's water supply was hit due to fly-ash in Kanhan river in August," he said.Goswami further said that fly-ash was carcinogenic and caused many ailments among humans. "NMC should lodge a police complaint against Mahagenco for discharging fly-ash into Kanhan and contaminating the city's water supply. It should realize its responsibility and stop protecting Mahagenco officials," he added.Former energy minister Chandrashekhar Bawankule had tried to ensure utilization of Mahagenco's fly-ash by setting up a fly-ash industrial cluster near Koradi. The plan was to invite brick manufacturers to set up their kilns in the cluster and make them use fly-ash in bricks.However, the plan failed to take off as brick kiln owners refused to move into the cluster complaining that plot sizes allotted to them were not adequate. The local authorities - Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) and Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT) - were expected to evict them from their locations near residential areas but this activity did not progress beyond notice stage. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Ally: Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air (CREA)
Opponent: Khaparkheda CE Prakash Khandare, brick kiln owners

Title: Gurugram's air very poor again, control room set up for complaints
Body:
GURUGRAM: The city's air pollution levels were in the 'very poor' category on Tuesday. While an Air Quality Index (AQI) of 320 was recorded at the Teri Gram and Sector 51 monitoring stations, it stood at 277 (poor) at Vikas Sadan.
Track the pollution level in your cityThe stations are monitored by the Haryana State Pollution Control Board (HSPCB), which shares the data with the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB). HSPCB officials said that climatic conditions have led to a peak in air pollution levels over the past week. "The decrease in the temperature and wind speed has caused the increase in air pollution levels," said Kuldeep Singh, HSPCB regional officer, Gurugram.Singh said the city's air quality in the coming days will depend on the weather conditions as well as the level of stubble burning in neighbouring areas. Meanwhile, a control room has been set up for handling complaints related to air pollution in Faridabad and Gurugram with a dedicated helpline and nodal officer under the graded response action plan (GRAP). The control room for Gurugram has been set up in IMT Manesar. Residents can file complaints on toll-free number 18001800091 and via WhatsApp on 9717990677. Emails related to pollution can be sent to hspcbmc@gmail.com.After a few months of clean air, the air pollution levels in the national capital region have increased amidst increasing farm fires. GRAP measures, including a ban on diesel generators, came into effect in Delhi-NCR from October 15. While Gurugram got relief from the ban, the rest of the restrictions are being implemented."We are taking all the measures as directed by the EPCA including construction ban and night patrolling. All the measures are being implemented by the agencies concerned with the district administration as the nodal agency," said Singh. MCG has already issued fines to several people under GRAP and it has been announced that those fined under GRAP will have to pay the fines within seven days. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: October 28, 2020
Hero: Haryana State Pollution Control Board (HSPCB), HSPCB regional officer Kuldeep Singh
Villain: stubble burning, farm fires, diesel generators
Ally: EPCA

Title: EPCA to discuss prep with 3 states today
Body:
Gurgaon: The Environment Pollution (Prevention & Control) Authority (EPCA) will hold a meeting with Haryana, Delhi and Uttar Pradesh pollution department on Thursday. They will discuss preparedness for implementation of Graded Response Action Plan (GRAP) in the region by next week keeping in view the increase in pollutants level.S Narayan, member secretary of Haryana State Pollution Control Board (HSPCB), said, "We will have a meeting with EPCA on Thursday before implementing the GRAP next week. The discussion will be on the preparedness before implementation of GRAP in the region. 
We already had four meetings with EPCA about the current situation and how effectively the plan can be implemented this year to curb pollution." According to GRAP, if the air turns "very poor" then the local administration should stop use of diesel generator sets, increase bus and metro services and increasing frequency of metro service and stop use of coal/firewood in hotels and open eateries. On Wednesday, Gurgaon's AQI was recorded at 194.When inquired about implementing GRAP in Gurgaon, deputy commissioner said that they are awaiting direction of EPCA. Amit Khatri, deputy commissioner, Gurgaon, said, "We will implement GRAP as per the direction of environment department."Meanwhile, Haryana State Pollution Control Board (HSPCB) said that they are working towards mitigating air pollution. Shakti Singh, regional officer, HSPCB, "We are well prepared for implementing GRAP in the district. As per the GRAP, when the air quality is between moderate to poor, it has been advised to enforce pollution control in thermal power plants, mechanized sweeping on roads, ban on firecrackers and stop garbage burning. At present, Gurgaon air quality is in the 'moderate' category. Hence, once GRAP is implemented the respective departments will carry out their duties as per the air quality and criteria in GRAP."Moreover, if the air quality turns "severe" then measures such as increase frequency of mechanized sweeping of road and sprinkling of water on roads, close brick kilns, hot mix plants, stone crushers, Shut down power plant, introduce concessional rates to encourage off-peak travel in public transport should be followed. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com
