Title: Chhattisgarh to introduce best electric vehicle policies, says transport minister
Body:
RAIPUR: Chhattisgarh will soon draft a policy on electric vehicles (EV) in collaboration, which will be the best in country, said state transport minister Mohd Akbar during a virtual conclave on Tuesday."Air pollution is a serious global issue, and there is an urgent need to promote electric vehicles in the country and make the most of solar energy as well," the minister said, adding that the state government is ready to assist and support organizations and industries working in EV and solar sectors in all possible ways.Akbar mentioned that such programmes shall help the department to attract investment in the state and help them implement the policies - which are in the pipeline - to the general masses."I invite industry experts from across the country to come forward and give their valuable inputs to the officials in the transport department so that a robust EV policy can be drafted and implemented too," Mohd Akbar said.Additional commissioner, transport department Dipanshu Kabra spoke about the challenges and scope around EV infrastructure and stressed upon coming up with innovative solutions that can prove to be effective in preparing a strong and economically viable roadmap for electric vehicles in state.Assistant transport commissioner Shailabh Sahu said, "There are two major points we need to consider for electric vehicles. First is the range. How far an EV can travel once charged and secondly its cost. 
EVs are costlier than regular petrol or diesel vehicles. If we are going for a shift to EVs we need to keep these two factors into consideration. Hence, for policymaking, it's essential to introduce innovative ideas to make EVs affordable for the public and work with companies to enhance the range of these vehicles."He said that there are subsidies and incentives offered by the state governments in other states to encourage selling of EVs. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: September 14, 2021
Hero: state transport minister Mohd Akbar, state government
Ally: EV, solar industries, Additional commissioner transport department Dipanshu Kabra, Assistant transport commissioner Shailabh Sahu

Title: NCR Planning Board gives another month to states to respond to proposals on Regional Draft Plan 2041
Body:
NEW DELHI: The NCR Planning Board (NCRPB) on Tuesday gave another one month's time to the participating states to submit their comments before putting the Regional Draft Plan 2041 in public domain for consultation as states sought more time to respond to the proposals. The proposed plan envisages major infrastructure projects and increased economic activities across the region.Sources said Union minister Hardeep Singh Puri, who chaired the meeting, flagged how delay in finalising the Regional Plan won't be acceptable this time while highlighting how some years were lost when the last Regional Plan for 2021 was prepared.TOI has learnt that only Haryana chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar was present in the virtual meeting while all the three other states were represented by their ministers. Sources said Khattar flagged his concern over how a large share of the state's territory has come under the jurisdiction of NCR.Officials said no other major issue barring the Draft Regional Plan was taken up in the meeting. 
In an official release, the housing and urban affairs ministry said Puri urged the NCR participating states to adopt and implement the recommendations of the NCRPB's plans and make use of its funding window available at very attractive rates, which will help in achieving accelerated growth and development of all sectors in the region.It said the Haryana, Rajasthan, Delhi and Uttar Pradesh governments signed the Combined Reciprocal Common Transport Agreement (CRCTA) for Stage Carriage and Contract Carriage for seamless movement of passenger vehicles in the NCR. "There will be single point taxation for all motor cabs/ taxis/ auto rickshaw; all stage carriage buses, all State Transport Undertakings (STUs) of NCR, including city bus services. This will encourage shift of traffic from private vehicles to mass public transport vehicles and will help in to ease traffic congestion and reduce air pollution," the ministry said. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: August 31, 2021
Hero: Haryana, Rajasthan, Delhi and Uttar Pradesh governments
Moral Description: Allow free movement with public transport without taxes

Title: Managing BP is crucial to prevent stroke: Dr Vijaya
Body:
GUNTUR: Stating that one in four people suffer a stroke in their lifetime, noted neurologist and Indian Stroke Association (ISA) leader Dr P Vijaya said that managing blood pressure is very vital to prevent stroke. She said that air pollution and sedentary lifestyles were also leading to stroke among many people. 
Addressing an awareness programme jointly organized by ISA and Rotary club of Guntur, Rotary club of Aadarsh, Rotary club of Guntur Vikas and Rotary club of Guntur Centennial on Sunday, Dr Vijaya, director of Lalitha Super Specialty hospitals group, observed that people should keep their hypertension and blood pressure levels under check to overcome the ill-effects of stroke. She said that keeping away from smoking and alcohol would immensely help prevent stroke. She said that people with heart diseases, high cholesterol levels and obesity should be very careful to safeguard themselves from falling victims to the stroke. "Everyone can know about their risk through the Stroke Riskometer App, which is available in the play store. Take all possible measures to prevent stroke and take assistance from a doctor soon after getting doubt about a possible stroke," suggested Dr Vijaya. She said that the ISA has taken up aggressive campaign to help save lives. She said that they wanted to stop the first attack among people with risk factors through the campaign and second attack after a person suffers with TIA or stroke. "Everyone more than 35 years should check their Blood Pressure levels and manage it to prevent stroke," said Dr.Vijaya. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: October 17, 2021
Hero: neurologist and Indian Stroke Association (ISA) leader Dr P Vijaya, ISA and Rotary club of Guntur, Rotary club of Aadarsh, Rotary club of Guntur Vikas and Rotary club of Guntur Centennial

Title: Navi Mumbai: Why were 26 trees razed at MIDC plot in Pawane, asks NCP activist
Body:
NAVI MUMBAI: A senior Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) activist has raised a serious environmental issue with MIDC over the shocking destruction of 26 green and healthy trees from a Pawane land plot that was earlier allotted to Shree Ganesh Forgings Limited industrial company.Talking to TOI, NCP's national general secretary (minority department) Saleem Sarang said, "Since February this year, I have been formally asking the planning body, MIDC, as to how and why over 26 big trees were fully razed at the Ganesh Forgings plot that was later given to the Goodwill group to run their business. However, till date I have not got a proper explanation or response on why the trees were killed or shifted elsewhere. Some of these tall trees were within the protected 3-metre borderline periphery of the plot C-3/C, still they were illegally removed. 
This is highly harmful for the environment, but the authorities are least bothered."Sarang further added, "`Today (Thursday) I personally met the state deputy chief minister, Ajit Pawar, to complain about how green trees are being brazenly killed without any fear of law, such as at this Pawane plot. After researching on this issue, I also got to know that earlier an FIR was done against unknown persons for killing a tree at the Goodwill group plot at Vashi sector 17, where the landmark Apna Bazaar building once stood. If MIDC still fails to reply to my queries, then I will be forced to move the Bombay high court, for the sake of greenery and protection of our city trees.''When TOI contacted the MIDC regional head, Satish Bagal, on this tree issue, he said, "I will have to check the file documents of the Ganesh Forgings plot (now handed over to Goodwill group) to know more about the trees matter."RTI activist Anarjit Chouhan commented, "MIDC is the planning body for the industrial zone in Navi Mumbai. Hence, they are responsible for the number of trees in all their plots. If anyone has hacked trees or even transplanted them, the planning body must take note of it and act as per the environmental laws. If no action is taken against culprits, then our green tree cover will continue to reduce, which will be our loss in our fight against air pollution.'' For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: October 14, 2021
Hero: Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) activist, NCP's national general secretary (minority department) Saleem Sarang
Ally: RTI activist Anarjit Chouhan

Title: How GMDA plans to stop roads from being dug up for infrastructural work
Body:
Gurgaon: In a bid to restrict excavation and open digging and preserve green belts, the Gurugram Metropolitan Development Authority (GMDA) is planning to make the use of "trenchless machines" mandatory in the laying of underground utilities in areas within its jurisdiction.Trenchless machines enable the installation, removal, or maintenance of utilities by minimising or removing the need for open excavation. GMDA officials said the machines will prevent operators from dumping soil in green belts, help preserve roads, reduce disruptions normally caused by excavation, ensure faster work and also help in curtailing air pollution, an especially critical factor during the upcoming winter months.According to officials, the matter had come up for discussion during a meeting of GMDA's core planning cell (CPC) last month, following which the CPC had directed that trenchless machines be used for laying utilities. The chief engineers of infrastructure 1 and 2 divisions were also directed to draft a "policy decision" for the use of trenchless machines so that open digging may be restricted."As of now, utilities are mostly being laid through open digging, which means excavating the portion. 
For example, in case of a road, one person digs up the road, then another comes and does some other work, then a third again digs it up for another reason. Such things weaken the road, which is continuously broken and relaid. The aim of using trenchless machines is to prevent this from happening. It will help maintain roads, green belts and other GMDA assets," said a senior GMDA official."Once this policy is adopted, it will be mandatory for any operator carrying out work in the right of way (ROW) of GMDA to use trenchless machines instead of indulging in open digging. Around 95% of infrastructural work is possible through this method. If there are instances where work cannot be done through this means and open digging is required, the requirement will be assessed on a case-to-case basis by the authority. A policy decision is being worked upon," the official said.At the CPC meeting last month, the GMDA chief executive officer had also directed the chief engineers to ensure that a ground penetrating radar survey is done by every applicant applying for work within ROW of GMDA, and the applicant submits an as-built drawing after execution of the work. While the GPR survey shows the placement of utilities in terms of both location and depth prior to construction, as-built drawings depict the area where the work was undertaken after it is completed.The GMDA chief had also directed that officials should ensure that a bank guarantee for the work is obtained and it is sufficient to ensure that the applicant uses trenchless machines to complete the work.GMDA has been working on several plans to make the process of laying and maintaining utilities in the city smoother and faster, including procuring a GPR machine of its own and mapping all utilities laid down by different agencies and making the data available to the public on the OneMap portal. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: October 5, 2021
Hero: Gurugram Metropolitan Development Authority (GMDA)
Ally: core planning cell (CPC)

Title: Diwali firecrackers: HSI issues 'sound' advice for pet owners
Body:
CHENNAI: This year, with the number of Covid-19 cases coming down, people are looking forward to celebrating Diwali with more fervour, hoping that the festival of lights will usher in a bright future after the gloom and doom of the pandemic. But even as people shop for clothes and sweets, cracker stalls are also doing brisk business. Unfortunately, even as people celebrate, animals and birds get injured and sick, with the rise in air and noise pollution. Many pets also run away from home and end up on the streets and in animal shelters. 
That's why animal lovers and NGOs are requesting people to celebrate a noise-free, animal friendly Diwali."Diwali is a vibrant time for people but can often lead to extreme stress and discomfort for pets and street animals. We urge everyone to celebrate the festival of lights as it is meant to be celebrated - with lamps, lights, sweets and delicious savouries and not loud firecrackers. This year, more than ever, we must consider the safety and wellness of others including the old, the young and the animals who are all sensitive to noise pollution. We also request our citizens to follow Covid-19 precautions and guidelines issued by the government," says Alokparna Sengupta, managing director of HSI/ India.The organisation has also put out some 'sound' advice for citizens who want to help animals around them:~ Keep your pets indoors and in a familiar room. Pets have a heightened sense of hearing, so jolts and loud noises cause many animals to flee in search of a safe haven. Leave on calming music or the television, if possible.~ Keep all doors and windows closed and draw the curtains to reduce the noise. Supply pets with enough food and water and ensure someone can stay with them to comfort them.~ Urge people to avoid igniting loud firecrackers and instead use firecrackers that emit less smoke and do not create much noise.~ Store fireworks safely in a closed box, somewhere cool and dry, and out of reach of pets. Do not keep firework containers under stairs or exposed in passages.~ Decorate with lights, lamps and diyas that are friendlier to the environment and animals (i.e., ones that give off less smoke and noise.)~ Refrain from setting firecrackers off near an animal shelter or zoo. The loud explosion can cause panic and fear. Pollution from burning firecrackers is harmful to their health.~ Take dogs for a walk during the daytime before the celebrations begin. Never walk them near where others are lighting firecrackers.~ Consult a veterinarian if your pets are prone to acute anxiety or distress from loud noises and give anti-anxiety medicines, if necessary and only through a vet's prescription. Check their availability during Diwali, ahead of time, in case of an emergency.~ Ensure pets are wearing collars and identification tags with current contact information. All pets, even those kept indoors, should always wear collars with identification tags.~ If you feed street animals around your neighbourhood, make sure they are wearing tags labelled with their names and your phone numbers. Provide them shelter in an area where they may be safe from the firecrackers and the noise.~ Make a first-aid kit in preparation for helping injured animals. Have a bucket full of water handy for an emergency and to place used sparklers inside.~ Keep contact information for local municipal corporations and surrounding shelters handy and approach them immediately in case of lost pets. If you find lost pets, either take them to the address on the tag or a local animal shelter. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: November 2, 2021
Hero: animal lovers and NGOs

Title: AQI 'poor' for 3 days, health dept says stay indoors
Body:
Gurgaon: First Covid, now bad air. The health department has asked Gurgaon residents to avoid stepping out of homes unless absolutely necessary as the city's air quality has remained in the "poor" category for three days on the trot.Should people have to step out urgently, they should wear masks all the time and consult a doctor in case of breathing problems, giddiness, chest discomfort, cough and irritation in the eyes. The department has also asked people to avoid areas that witness heavy trafficOn Sunday, Gurgaon recorded an AQI of 262. An AQI in the 201 to 300 range is considered "poor" while that between 301 and 400 is "very poor". Officials fear the air quality may turn worse in the coming week. 
According to the Central Pollution Control Board, air quality in the "poor" range can cause breathing discomfort in case of prolonged exposure and even respiratory illnesses. Officials said children should be made to wear air filter masks in case they step out of homes. "People with airway, lungs or heart illnesses should have medicines available with them. They should avoid going for morning and evening walks. Doors and windows should be kept closed in the mornings and evenings," said Virender Yadav, the chief medical officer.He also stressed that people should not burst crackers, even in areas where they would be allowed during the festivals. "Harmful gases such as sulphur dioxide are emitted when you burn crackers. These gases affect the ozone layer. Since the particulate matter's size is 2.5, they easily enter our body through the nasal vessels and settle into our lungs. At times, PM 2.5 gets absorbed into our blood vessels as well. These have an effect on the respiratory system. This is why people should avoid outdoor activities during peak pollution hours," Yadav added.Doctors backed the health department advisory. "As the winter settles, the air quality is slowly becoming poor. There is a rise in the number of respiratory cases such as viral pneumonia, asthma and COPD. Such patients have difficulty breathing, cough, fever, increased sputum and sleep disturbances. Such people should wear masks, continue preventive therapies and consider vaccinations for flu and pneumonia after consulting a doctor," said Dr Manoj Goel, director of pulmonology at Fortis Hospital. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: November 1, 2021
Hero: Dr Manoj Goel, central pollution control board, Virender Yadav chief medical officer

Title: Lucknow: Saturday 2nd most polluted day of November
Body:
LUCKNOW: The city witnessed a spike in pollution levels by around 150 units in the last five days, with the air quality deteriorating from poor to 'very poor' on Saturday.According to the data released by the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), the city's Air Quality Index was 317. As compared to Friday, the air pollution level registered an increase of over 32 units in just 24 hours making the weekend, the second most air polluted day of the month.
Track the pollution level in your cityA high concentration of nano pollutants of PM2.5 and PM10 was registered in all main localities of the city, including Hazratganj, Lalbagh, Indiranagar, Nishatganj, Kukrail, Gomtinagar and Talkatora, where the average concentration in morning and evening hours crossed an alarming 350-mark. Environmentalists said the spike in air pollution level is majorly due to a drop in temperatures, an increase in vehicular load due to rush in markets following the wedding season and low wind speed.According to CPCB live air quality monitoring station, PM 2.5 concentrations were found to be around six times higher than the permissible limit of 60 and PM 10 concentrations were found to be around four times higher than the permissible limits set by the National Ambient Air Quality Standards. The last time the air pollution levels of the city crossed the 300-mark was on November 8, when air pollution level was 338 and on November 1 when AQI was 308."Entire November has been in the grip of poor air quality. The situation is expected to worsen in December and January due to further drop in temperatures. A plan of action needs to be prepared and implemented with immediate effect to control this rapid rise in air pollution levels, else the air quality of the city will turn 'severe' in the next few days," said environmentalist Prof Venkatesh Dutta. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: November 28, 2021
Hero: environmentalist Prof Venkatesh Dutta
Ally: Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB), Environmentalists

Title: Transport dept to map out routes for public vehicles in Bihar
Body:
PATNA: Following the concept of vehicle carrying capacity of road, the state transport department will map out the routes for public vehicles like autorickshaws, e-rickshaws and buses for faster mobility as well as to free up choked roads and improve the air quality. It will be initially implemented in Patna and neighbouring areas like Danapur, Khagaul and Phulwarisharif. The department is developing a software to help decide the routes for public vehicles through geographic information system (GIS). Transport officials have started the manual survey for urban public transport route planning, which includes the number of public vehicles, routes on which the vehicles are plying, travel demand pattern and exploring new routes.Transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said the number of public vehicles has been increasing in the state capital, causing huge traffic congestion on several routes and rise in air pollution. 
"To regulate the volume of traffic and rush on several roads, the department will chalk out the routes for autorickshaws, e-rickshaws and even buses, based on the survey report. We will hold a meeting with all the stakeholders, including public transport associations and ward councillors to check the requirement of public vehicles," he said.Agarwal said there are surplus autorickshaws on some routes like Patna Junction and Gandhi Maidan while huge deficit in public transport services persists in some areas. "As per the number of public vehicles, we will plan the routes for autorickshaws, e-rickshaws and buses and how many vehicles will be run on each route will depend on the vehicle carrying capacity of the road," he said."The department will issue permit to new vehicles with routes mentioned while the old vehicles will be streamlined. Once this is implemented, all details regarding autorickshaws, e-rickshaws and buses, including the contact number and name of the drivers, will be available at a click. It will also help in tracking a vehicle in case of any emergency situation," he added. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: November 19, 2021
Hero: state transport department, Transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal
Ally: public transport

Title: 70 new stations to monitor air quality
Body:
Kolkata: Seventy sensor-based air and noise quality monitoring stations went live in Kolkata and rest of the state on Tuesday morning. Eighty more stations are likely to come up soon.WBPCB is setting up a Central Command Centre at its headquarters, where its team of scientists and analysts will study the data round the clock in real time to come up with comprehensive, actionable data for short- and long-term mitigation measures. Operated by West Bengal Pollution Control Board (WBPCB), these stations will provide real-time air and noise data, along with a couple of meteorological details, to make the network robust and intensive in the country. 
The sensor based monitoring will include PM1 (ultra-fine particulate matter), which will be used for research, as Central Pollution Control Board has not yet included PM1 monitoring in its mandate.These 70 stations are part of the ambitious '150 station project' that WBPCB has taken up. Once the entire project is ready, it will be a network of 243 stations, including its 79 manual and 14 continuous ambient air quality monitoring stations (CAAQMS). "National Green Tribunal (NGT) asked us to monitor the air quality of all seven non-attainment cities Barrackpore, Haldia, Durgapur, Asansol, Ranigunj, Kolkata and Howrah. Apart from complying with the NGT order, we have extended the monitoring network, particularly along the border of the state. A recent study of IIT-Delhi showed 53% of the city's pollution is contributed by trans-border pollution, 21% of it from Bangladesh. A massive amount of this pollution constitutes dust caused by erosion of farmland top soil," said WBPCB chairman Kalyan Rudra.During winter, he said, pollutants of the Indo-Gangetic Plain travelled easily to Kolkata, situated at the tail end of the plain. This is why the air quality monitoring along the borders helped us understand the dynamism of air pollution and underlined the requirement of a regional approach for its mitigation measures, he said.Kolkata Police commissioner Soumen Mitra said, "Climate change is no more a possibility of the future but is already at play at our doorsteps. We are getting affected by the delayed onset of seasons and longer inundation because of erratic monsoon. Police have a major role to play in containing social unrest induced by climate change. We have started making our force aware of the dangers of air pollution, noise pollution, climate changes, plastic waste and absence of waste segregation. We are trying to turn our academic campuses green and minimize waste generation by adopting segregation of wastes and composting."WBPCB member secretary Roshni Sen said, "Air quality affects us all. We can't escape it by confining ourselves to our home as several studies have hinted that indoor air is often worse than ambient air. We all need to work in unison to improve the air quality." For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: December 29, 2021
Hero: West Bengal Pollution Control Board (WBPCB), National Green Tribunal (NGT), WBPCB chairman Kalyan Rudra, WBPCB member secretary Roshni Sen

Title: Opposition mocks govt over recovery of alcohol bottles on House premises
Body:
PATNA: The RJD legislators on Wednesday demonstrated outside the Bihar Vidhan Parishad over illegal liquor trade in Bihar. Leader of opposition in the state assembly, Tejashwi Prasad Yadav, took a jibe at the state government for empty liquor bottles found on the premises of state legislature. He said the number of bottles were being counted, instead of investigating as to how these bottles reached there."They are coming up with stunning things. 
Had they worked on prohibition seriously, they would have not been ashamed," said Tejashwi. His mother and former chief minister Rabri Devi also demonstrated outside the legislature building over illegal liquor trade in Bihar. In the legislative council, RJD MLC Rambali Singh demanded the House adjournment. Sharing a data of National Family Health Survey-5, Singh said 15% of the state population was consuming liquor, while in Maharashtra, the percentage was less than in Bihar. "This is the mockery of prohibition. It is a shame that liquor bottles have been recovered from the premises of Vidhan Sabha," he said.JD(U) MLC Neeraj Kumar asked Singh to tell who had informed them about the empty bottles. "After getting the information, did you call on the toll-free number or the number released by KK Pathak? You did not fulfil your responsibility," said Neeraj. Without naming anyone, he said an RJD leader's son was found in a drunken state, but the party has taken no action yet.Singh then reminded Neeraj of liquor bottles seized from a school run by the brother of a cabinet minister.Congress MLC Prem Chandra Mishra raised the issue of increase in crime in Madhubani district and mentioned several incidents, including assault on a judge in Jhankharpur by the cops, murder of scribe Avinash Jha, who had exposed the fake hospitals and dead body of a girl Gulshan recovered from officer's colony in Madhubani. MLC Sanjeev Shyam Singh raised the issue of increase in air pollution in different towns of Bihar. BJP MLC Sanjay Prakash alias Sanjay Mayukh backed Singh and asked the government to take this issue seriously. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: December 2, 2021
Hero: MLC Sanjeev Shyam Singh
Moral Description: Issue of air pollution was raised, but article mainly about alcohol being found on government premises

Title: How Indian coir became a money-spinner for China
Body:
For many, Pollachi in Tamil Nadu may bring to mind tall coconut trees and mounds of coconut husks being dried in large plots of land. One of the largest producers of coconut in the country, the district is yet to reap the full benefits of this resource.While the coir industry is growing at a rate of 10-15% every year, there has been a negative growth in the value of coir because of negligible attempts to make value-added products despite the availability of raw coir in abundance. So, while globally there is a demand for coir wood, geotextiles, mattresses and mattings, Pollachi units are stuck on making coir pith and exporting raw coir fibre.The potential of coconut fibre or coir, which comprises 60% of the husk, largely remains untapped, says industry insiders. A recent announcement by the Tamil Nadu government on establishing a coir processing cluster in Pollachi is considered a step towards realising its potential, but there is a long way to go.The district has about 600 coir mills that defibre coconuts and export the raw coir fibre to China after extracting coco pith. 
Instead, the coir can be converted into yarn, mattress, floor mats and doormats."Data reveals that of the 9 lakh tonnes of coir produced in the country, nearly 7.5 lakh tonnes are exported to China, and a similar trend is witnessed in Pollachi," said SK Gowthaman, a member of the Coir Board.The product most Pollachi units focus on at present is coir pith and its ancillary products, which is a change from the 1990s, when coir processing units started coming up. The units were primarily engaged in extracting the coir fibre out of coconut husk and sending it to Kerala to be converted into value-added products such as mattresses and other material. Coco pith had no value then and was burned on the roadsides.The trend reversed in the next 20 years when coco pith's water retaining capacity made it popular as an alternative to soil. In 2015, coco pith was such a big hit in agriculture and gardening that the coir industry in Pollachi was running with its profits."The cost of coco pith, which was ?2.5 a kg in the early 2000s, has now increased to ?25 a kg. But the value of coir didn't grow as it was just exported as a raw material to China," said Gowthaman.About a decade ago, when China entered the Indian market for importing coir fibre to make value-added products such as mattresses, Pollachi became its sourcing centre. Over the years, the dependence on the Chinese markets has increased to such an extent that Pollachi units suffer when China stops importing coir for about three weeks during their new year at the end of January every year.While globally, there has been a demand for value-added coir fibre products, most units in Pollachi haven't been able to catch on to that trend."In the early 2000s, the rate of export of coir to China was ?500-700 for 30kg, now it has been ?250-350 for the past four years. This is because products and not raw coir bring in the revenue," said Gowthaman.S Mahesh Kumar of the Federation of Indian Coir Exporters Association (FICEA) said he has stopped exporting coir fibre to China. "People are starting to move to natural fibre, which is a positive sign for the coir industry," he said. He has started producing value-added products such as bags, slippers and mattresses that are in demand in the international and domestic markets.B Karthigaivasan, general manager, district industries centre (DIC), said the coir processing cluster announced by the state government is a move towards addressing the gap in the industry and the market. About 35 entrepreneurs in the coir industry have formed a special purpose vehicle (SPV) for establishing the cluster. The cluster will be formed at a cost of ?23.7 crore, of which the Centre will spend ?12 crore, the state ?2 crore and rest will be borne by the SPV.The cluster will have four machineries, which include coir quilting machine, coir needle punch machine, coir sheet production with latex spray and coir tufted mats with latex. Besides this, a laboratory for coir testing will also be part of the cluster, he said.The new prospects, however, need to be eco-friendly as well as the Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) has enforced stricter pollution control norms for coir pith units. P Manimaran, Coimbatore district environment engineer at TNPCB, stressed on the need for coir processing units to upgrade their facilities as per the present pollution control norms."The problem arises in the conventional process wherein the husk is piled up in agricultural land and sprayed with water for extraction of coir and coco pith. This leads to contamination of groundwater. When it is left to dry in the field, the coco pith particles are suspended, resulting in air pollution. There is advanced machinery available that can segregate the husk with minimal effluent discharge," said Manimaran. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: January 19, 2022
Hero: Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB), Coimbatore district environment engineer at TNPCB

Title: IIT-Delhi startup launches "world's smallest" wearable air purifier, Naso95
Body:
IIT-Delhi start-up Nanoclean Global has launched the "world's smallest" wearable air purifier, Naso95. Nanoclean Global claims that Naso95 is at par effective to an N95 grade face mask. The launch ceremony at IIT Delhi observed gathering from Doctors and Government officials. 
Shri. Rajesh Kumar Pathak, IP & TAFS cadre, Secretary Technology Development Board, Gov. of India was the chief guest and Dr M C Mishra, Ex Director AIIMS, Delhi was guest of honour. What is Naso95 and how it works Naso95 is an N95 grade nasal filter. It sticks to the user's nasal orifice and prevents bacteria, viral infection and pollen and air pollution. It is at par effective with an N95 grade face mask.According to the company, a person wearing Naso95 is more protected than a generic facemask or a loosely fitted face mask. The product is said to have been tested and certified by national and international labs for its safety and efficiency. Naso95 comes in different sizes: Small, Medium, Large and Kids size.The product Naso95 can also be used by kids prone to air borne infections and air pollution. Dr M C Mishra, ex-director, AIIMS-Delhi, said that air pollution is a much bigger problem than viruses. Lung cancer remains the leading form of cancer and a product like Naso95 can effectively address the problem of respiratory illnesses in metro cities. During the pandemic, the product can specially come in handy at places where one has to pull down a mask for the purpose of identification for e.g. airports, security checks etc. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: February 24, 2022
Hero: AIIMS-Delhi ex-director Dr M C Mishra, IIT-Delhi start-up Nanoclean Global
Moral Description: Air pollution causes cancer, use these to stay alright

Title: Protect bus priority lane on ORR: NGO
Body:
Times News Network
Bengaluru: With bollards for the bus priority lane on Outer Ring Road (ORR) likely to be removed, Greenpeace India on Saturday demanded protection and expansion of BMTC lanes across the city. 
Its members painted messages such as 'protect the bus lane' on ORR. "Bengaluru has been experiencing very critical air quality for the past many years. Greenpeace India's recent report found the annual average of PM2.5 and PM10 exceed WHO's revised standards in the city. Previous source apportionment studies identified the transportation sector as one of the major sources of air pollution in the city," the NGO said in a statement. 
"Like in many other Indian cities, public transport in Bengaluru caters to majority of citizens and the bus priority lane particularly has reduced travel time, improved predictability, increased service supply along the corridor, and resulted in improved bus ridership and revenue. In fact, BMTC which comprises just 0.15% of the total vehicle population, helps 50% of the human population in the city access mobility," it said. 
The organisation also suggested that companies must encourage employees to adopt public transport while implementing flexible hybrid work policies. Campaign manager Avinash Chanchal said it is unfortunate that representatives of companies have been asking the government to reconsider the bus lane instead of urging it to strengthen public transport.

Title: Uttarakhand HC notes DU student's letter, asks why Oak leaves burnt
Body:
NAINITAL: Taking suo motu cognisance of a letter seeking a ban on open burning of Oak leaves in Nainital by Medha Pandey, a fifth-semester LLB student at Delhi University (DU), the Uttarakhand high court (HC) on Wednesday asked why the leaves shed by trees in forests of Nainital were being burnt by sanitation workers, adding to air pollution in the lake town, when they can be turned into manure instead. Pandey also pointed out that open burning of waste is prohibited by the National Green Tribunal (NGT) across the country. A division bench of acting Chief Justice Sanjay Kumar Mishra and Justice RC Khulbe sent notices in this regard to the Union ministry of environment, forest & climate change (MoEF&CC), the Uttarakhand government, district magistrate of Nainital and nagar palika parishad, Nainital. 
The respondents have been asked to submit their replies within four weeks. Pandey, a resident of Nainital, had written the letter to the chief justice of HC on March 23. In the letter, she pointed out that "Nainital is surrounded by oak forests and the dried leaves keep falling on roads, streets and roofs." "Local residents and sanitation workers burn them, which affects the health of the environment as well as that of residents," the letter said, adding that oak leaves can be put to good use if turned into manure. "The leaves can also be deposited on forest floors, where they would retain the ground's moisture and shelter insects and snakes. Moreover, it is noticed that burning of dry leaves adjacent to forest areas can sometimes result in fire spreading to the forested area, leading to widespread forest fires," Pandey wrote in the letter, adding that "imposing a ban on burning of leaves will help increase water retention capacity in the forests of Nainital". Title: Green fuel push: West Bengal offers registration fee immunity, tax breather for CNG, e-vehicles
Body:
KOLKATA: In a bid to encourage and fast-track adoption of vehicles powered by green fuel, the state government on Friday announced exemption of registration fees and that of road tax for two years on electric two-wheelers and cars and all categories of CNG vehicles.Adoption of vehicles with cleaner fuel will pave the way for a better environment as petrol and diesel-powered vehicles contribute to 30% of the city's ambient air pollution. While there is no emission in electric vehicles, CNG burns cleaner than petrol and diesel and emits 80% less carbon monoxide and 44% less hydrocarbons. CNG cars also run quieter than gasoline and diesel vehicles.This one-time exemption of registration fees, tax, and additional tax would be effective from April 1, 2022 to March 31, 2024, stated the order issued by transport principal secretary Rajesh Kumar Sinha. 
According to the order, vehicles registered on or after April 1, 2022, till date of issuance of this notification, may get an extension of tax validity for the exact number of days for which tax has already been paid that falls within the period from April 1, 2022, to March 31, 2024. However, adjustment or refund of registration fees, if already paid, is disallowed. Electric vehicle manufacturers and environmentalists have been urging the state government to incentivise purchase of green-fuel vehicles that are more expensive than cars with internal combustion engines that run on petrol or diesel. Earlier, in the 2022-23 budget statement, minister of state for finance Chandrima Bhattacharya had announced a one-time exemption of tax and additional tax on battery-operated e-vehicles and on all categories of CNG-operated vehicles for the same period. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Hero: state government, minister of state for finance Chandrima Bhattacharya, transport principal secretary Rajesh Kumar Sinha

Title: Haryana to get its first 3 real-time noise monitoring stations - all in Faridabad
Body:
GURUGRAM : In the wake of growing concerns over noise levels breaching permissible limits, the Haryana State Pollution Control Board (HSPCB) plans to set up the state's first three real-time noise level monitoring stations in Faridabad. Equipped with digital display boards and connected to a centralised networking system, these stations will monitor noise levels continuously for 24 hours and around the year.Tenders inviting bids are out, and the board will award the work by mid-June. Faridabad is likely to get the three stations by August-end. 
According to HSPCB, these stations will help formulate an action plan for curbing noise pollution in the coming days. "We have opened the bidding for the project. June 6 is the last date for bids in response to the tender document for three real-time monitoring stations in Faridabad," HSPCB member secretary S Narayan told TOI.The HSPCB already has real-time ambient air quality monitoring stations at sectors 16A, 11, 30 and a new industrial area in Faridabad. The noise monitoring stations are likely to come up at three of these locations, but the pollution board is yet to take a final call.The values of various parameters measured in the noise monitoring stations shall be transferred online automatically and stored in the central server networking system, just like the air quality index data.The board has taken this initiative out of concerns over the increasing use of automobiles in the region, a primary cause of noise pollution. While noise pollution does not receive as much attention as air and water pollution, it impacts our health. According to the World Health Organisation (WHO), nearly 1.1 billion young people aged between 12-35 years are at risk of hearing loss due to noise exposure.Faridabad is the only Haryana district on the non-attainment cities' list of the National Clean Air Programme (NCAP), which means its air did not meet the national ambient air quality standards from 2011 to 15. So, it will be the first district to get the noise monitoring stations because the long-term plan is to ensure that, along with air pollution, noise pollution gets monitored for further analysis and creating a road map to curb the problems together.According to the noise standards for ambient air and automobiles, domestic appliances and construction equipment, notified in Environment (Protection) Rules, 1986, the limit is 55 decibels (dB) in residential areas, 65 dB in commercial areas, and 75 dB in industrial areas. Near sensitive areas such as hospitals, noise levels should not exceed 45 dB. At night, the limit is 45 dB in residential areas, 55dB in commercial areas, and 70 dB in industrial areas."This new project will help our department prepare a database, identify the dangerous sources of noise pollution and take adequate action," said an HSPCB officer. The plan is to expand the project to Gurugram , as well. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: May 31, 2022
Hero: Haryana State Pollution Control Board (HSPCB)

Title: New air regime: How MCD plans to tackle C&D waste
Body:
New Delhi: In its new policy on air pollution, the Commission for Air Quality Management has directed Delhi government's urban department and the urban local bodies to register all construction and demolition projects involving over 500 square metres on their web portals by August 30.Municipal Corporation of Delhi officials claimed to be verifying and monitoring construction sites and submitting details on a web portal developed by Delhi government. "CAQM's norms basically apply to big constructions and public works. MCD needs to give a self-declaration about the arrangements for clearing construction and demolition waste on the state government portal," said an MCD official.The official added, "We were taking the help of the building department to get details of ongoing construction and the works department for other development projects in areas under our jurisdiction. 
But during the unification of the municipal corporations, the process slowed down. Now we will again take appropriate measures in a time-bound manner."On July 9, Delhi's environment minister Gopal Rai announced a special campaign on self-registration of constructions on sites larger than 500sqm from July 15 to 30. The self-assessment portal was launched in October last year. The minister said, "As it is difficult to visit all construction and demolition sites, the project proponents have to compulsorily register on the portal and upload the self-declaration form on a fortnightly basis. Delhi Pollution Control Committee has been authorised to take action against defaulters."The CAQM policy instructs the local bodies to ensure segregation of C&D waste at the site and transport it to notified collection centres and processing plants. At present, the city generates 6,000-7,000 tonne of C&D waste per day. There are four C&D waste processing units capable of handling 4,150 TPD. Three others with a total capacity of 2,500 TPD are proposed at Ranikhera, Tehkhand and Libaspur by March 2023.The new pollution policy stresses on expansion of waste recycling capabilities, material recovery centres and timely completion of ongoing and planned infrastructure works. "We have 152 material recovery centres dealing with 228 TPD of waste. About 275 TPD are processed at the local level," said an MCD official.Officials claimed that in the next two years, they will be able to incinerate at least 8,000 tonnes of 11,000 tonnes of municipal waste at new waste-to-energy plants. "We are in the process of calling for bids for the proposed WTE plant at Bawana, while the one at Tehkhand will become operational by September end," added the official. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: July 18, 2022
Hero: Commission for Air Quality Management, Delhi's environment minister Gopal Rai
Ally: Delhi government's urban department, urban local bodies

Title: LG: Dust from unpaved roads major factor in air pollution
Body:
New Delhi: Lieutenant governor VK Saxena on Saturday appreciated the new graded response action plan put forward by the Centre's air quality panel and instructed all the implementing agencies to work in coordination to tackle Delhi's air pollution.At a meeting held with the members of the panel and agencies, the LG pointed out that 26% of the air pollution is generated from the dust due to unpaved roads and central verges. He asked the officials concerned to cover, repair, or carpet the roads and central verges within fixed deadlines. 
He also directed the officials to discard the "self-defeating prevalent practice" of laying interlocking blocks on reinforced cement concrete and rather opt for interlocking blocks by compaction, which will allow water to seep down and reduce cost of construction.He stressed that measures to control air pollution from vehicular emission, road and C&D dust, burning of solid municipal and agro waste and industrial emissions should be taken without any delay.The LG claimed that the total length of dust-generating, non-paved and open roadsides belonging to the PWD and municipal corporation was 165 km and 59.7 km, respectively.Saxena asked the air panel members to explore the possibility of installing rotating mist sprinklers on highrise buildings. He asked the environment department to immediately provide funds to the corporation for purchase of mechanised sweeping machines. "He also asked for fixed separate colour codes to be adopted by different road-owning agencies so as to make the ownership and responsibility related to it, easily identifiable," said a statement from the LG office. Title: PWD to install kerbside EV charging points across Delhi: Explained
Body:
The Delhi government had recently announced plans to set up kerbside electric vehicle (EV) charging points across the city. Public Works Department (PWD) has now picked 20 road stretches for installation of these EV chargers as a part of the pilot project, while 55 roads in North-East and North-West districts have been deemed not feasible for the project so far.One of the main factors that decides the feasibility of the location is street parking capacity for EVs to stop and charge without affecting road usage. 
More areas are expected to be identified for the roll out of the project. That said, eight nodal officers have been appointed to coordinate among Dialogue and Development Commission (DDC), transport department and PWD on the project.Delhi government feels that kerbside charging is an emerging concept globally and that street lamp posts or dedicated charging points can be used for charging vehicles. PWD has approximately 1,400 km of roads under its jurisdiction, with one lakh lamp posts. The state government plans to put up 5,000 kerbside charging points across the capital over the next three years.The pilot project will aim at 100 kerbside chargers serviced equally by the power distribution companies like Delhi Transco Limited, BSES Rajdhani Power Limited, BSES Yamuna Power Limited and Tata Power Delhi Distribution Limited. Once EV chargers are installed on all major roads following the pilot, the deployment will be scaled across the city. The government is largely targeting electric two-wheeler and three-wheelers since they occupy less space on the road, but reportedly cause more air pollution than most of other vehicles. Title: Paddy stubble: Relief sought for farmers
Body:
Chandigarh: Asking the central government to compensate the farmers for managing crop stubble, Punjab environment minister Gurmeet Singh Meet Hayer said the state had given away 90,422 subsidised CRM (crop residue management) machines and would give away 32,100 more.
Speaking at the national conference of the state environment ministers, Hayer said Punjab was ready to contribute its share if the central government was ready to match it. The minister said: "The air pollution caused by stubble burning troubles not only Punjab but the entire country. Punjab brought the country out of food crisis and now, in its hour of need, the Centre should hold its hand. We are in a large-scale awareness campaign for the farmers and also reaching them out through university students."
The minister claimed that out of the second lot of 32,100 CRM machines to be given away, the state government had sanctioned 21,000. Also, the subsidy was 50% for individual farmers and 80% for panchayats or farming societies. Paddy straw is being used as fuel for electricity and biogas plants, Hayer claimed, adding this will make crop residuce a source of income for the farmers. tnn

Title: Bhopal coughs the morning after, AQI shoots to 264
Body:
Bhopal: Air quality across major cities of Madhya Pradesh was not fit to breathe on prolonged exposure due to Diwali fireworks. The air quality was not only poor, but was actually worse than the previous year, pointing out that people burst more fireworks this year as if to make up for the past two pandemic years. 
Due to bursting of crackers till late in the night, pollution levels go up the next morning after Diwali. On Tuesday, the air quality index in major MP cities including Bhopal, Indore, Gwalior and Jabalpur was rated poor by the central pollution control board and there was an increase of close to 20 points in the air quality index when compared to last year's morning after the Diwali night. 
Among the main cities, air quality of Gwalior was the worst followed by Bhopal, Jabalpur and Indore. The difference in the air quality index of the four cities was not huge, but the air quality index of all four cities ranged between 200 and 300, which is poor and may lead to breathing discomfort to most people on prolonged exposure.
The air quality index of Gwalior was 274, Bhopal 264, Jabalpur 223 and Indore was 209. It means the air pollution levels were lowest in Indore.
But when compared to last year, Jabalpur was the only city where pollution levels marginally went down this Diwali. The air quality index last year after the Diwali night was 260 in Gwalior, 244 of Bhopal, 197 of Indore and 244 of Jabalpur. It means pollution levels marginally went down in Jabalpur this year, though it continues to remain in the poor category.
There was no real attempt to enforce the cracker bursting schedule or to promote sale of green crackers.
Air quality is measured taking into account the levels of sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxide (Nox), RSPM10 and fine particulate matter (PM2.5) in the air. Of the four, officials said, PM2.5 is the most harmful to health since it causes severe lung diseases. AQI above 200 leads to breathing discomfort on prolonged exposure.

Title: 'Netas must go around coal-hit villages, see damage for themselves'
Body:
Leena Buddhe, who runs the Centre for Sustainable Development, has been taking up many issues related to farmers' sufferings due to coal pollution. Thanks to her, problems being faced by villages when it comes to pollution from coal-fired power plants and a coal washery in Nagpur district, has got state attention. Earlier this year, she brought in the then environment minister Aditya Thackeray to understand the problems of the villagers.TOI speaks to Buddhe on her findings, the rising catastrophes due to coal and the neglectful attitude of government agencies.Excerpts from an interview...Q. You have been working since a long time in the social sector. When did coal pollution catch your eye?
A. This was actually during the Covid pandemic when I was attending an online workshop organized by Pune-based research centre Manthan Adhyayan Kendra. Its founder Shripad Dharmadikari was giving a presentation on the severe pollution happening in our region due to coal-fired power plants. It then hit me that when experts from other cities are talking about it, we being a local organization should pay serious heed to it. Our fight against coal pollution started with curiosity but after six months of deep research and on-ground survey, we realized how grave the problem is.Q. What were your initial findings?A. We started by visiting villages that were impacted and building a rapport with the sarpanchs and locals. The first village we visited was Chakki Khapa which was almost 9 km from Koradi Thermal Power Plant. We were completely taken aback when we saw that the crops were all covered in coal dust. The farmers have been losing 30-40% of their agricultural yield because of this; health impacts aside. The fact that these plants are in existence for 2-3 decades and still nobody was raising their voice against pollution was quite surprising.Q. Why were the locals tight-lipped about it?A. The reason why these issues were not being highlighted was that there was no collective voice coming out from the villages. The power plant authorities would manipulate the villagers by telling them how they have given the latter jobs and electricity. What the locals didn't realize was that it was coming at the cost of their lives. When we interacted with the women self-help groups, we could sense that they are aware of all the impacts of pollution but don't complain as they fear that men would lose their jobs. Farmers would get job at the power plants in exchange of their agricultural fields.Q. How bad is the situation on ground? In what ways is pollution from power plants affecting public health and environment?A. It is much worse than we think it is. Do you know why one of the most impacted Khasala village is called New Khasala? Because the entire village was shifted from its original location to where it is now so that the power plant could discharge toxic fly-ash. Most of the villagers got a job at the plant and, today, there are hardly any farmers left. Not only has this taken them away from their roots but also exposed them to major public health threat. Even though the plant officials claim that the discharge is reused, majority of it finds its way to agricultural fields, nullahs and rivers which are major drinking water sources. And the massive air pollution that they are exposed too is another problem altogether.Q. The Khasala ash bund recently saw a major breach which submerged nearby villages and led to enormous losses. Do you think the catastrophes arising from coal plants have now increased?A. The reason why such mishaps are increasing is because the ash bunds of Koradi and Khaparkheda power plants are full to its brim as they have failed miserably in ensuring the mandatory utilization of fly-ash. Instead of clearing up their old bunds, they keep on acquiring agricultural lands and building new ones. And the worst part is that the regulatory bodies are not bothered. When a power plant writes on paper that they have used certain amount of fly-ash, what mechanism does the Maharashtra Pollution Control Board (MPCB) has to verify it? In our surveillance meetings, Mahagenco claims that they submit all pollution data to MPCB. My question is that why is this data not made public? Doesn't a sarpanch of a village has the right to know what kind of air they are breathing?Q. Do you feel that the regulatory bodies and the power generation company are hand-in-glove?A. From our interactions, one thing that is certainly clear is that the major problem is both being government bodies. When the Khasala ash bund breach happened, our question to MPCB was that whether they would have been this lenient had it been a private power plant. Just because these plants are state-owned, it doesn't give them the right to pollute. MPCB can prosecute the officials, file criminal complaints but it's not using its power for reasons best known to them. Are they hand-in-glove then? May be.Q. What role do politicians play in such a crisis?A. Politicians can play a major role. The whole situation depends on the sensitivity and understanding of the person in power. And we have seen some wonderful examples. Like when former state environment minister Aaditya Thackeray stopped discharge of fly-ash in Nandgaon. He could gauge and understand the damage it was doing. Politicians should go around villages, interact with the locals. They need to decide why they have come to power, for people or the coal industry?Q. It is absolutely impossible that Mahagenco is unaware of the damage it is doing. Still, it seems to be always on denial.A. Of course, the company is aware. Its website states that Mahagenco's vision is to take care of project-impacted people. But, in reality, it lacks sensitivity towards the locals. And when the power units buy them with jobs, people are scared to raise their voices. Villagers are not aware of their rights; their right to breathe clean air, drink clean water. And in many cases, people are scared to oppose such a powerful agency. This is why we have been focusing on mobilising and empowering locals. In one of our committee meetings, a sarpanch told Mahagenco officials, "aapne humare ghar ke saamne 314 acre mein raakh rakhi hai. Mai aapke ghar ke saamne do trucks bhar ke raakh rakh deta hun. Aap fir mujhe batana kaisa lagta hai". For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: October 23, 2022
Hero: research centre Manthan Adhyayan Kendra founder Shripad Dharmadikari, Leena Buddhe who runs the Centre for Sustainable Development, former state environment minister Aaditya Thackeray
Villain: coal-fired power plants, coal washery, Mahagenco
Opponent: Coal Industry, Maharashtra Pollution Control Board

Title: Chennai choked on toxic smoke on Diwali: Data
Body:
CHENNAI: Air pollution was severe in Chennai on Diwali, with Sowcarpet recording an AQI of 786, followed by Nungambakkam at 565, Valasaravakkam 545, Triplicane 503 and Thiruvotriyur 436. AQI in the 50-100 range is considered safe. Noise pollution too was high between 66 and 79.7 decibels. The normal is 65 decibels during daytime and 55 decibels at night.Cracker buffs celebrated Diwali with such vengeance this year, that Chennai overtook Delhi as the nation's most polluted city for two consecutive days. 
Chennai's air pollution was the highest in a decade.The air quality index of Chennai used to be in 50-100 range on a normal day when factories, thermal stations and vehicular pollution exist. On Monday, however, it shot up to maximum of 786 in Sowcarpet. At 345, Besant Nagar recorded the least. T Nagar recorded 372, while Triplicane at 503, Nungambakkam 565, Valasaravakkam 545 and Thiruvotriyur 436 also sizzled. Last year, the AQI on Diwali day ranged between 342 and 385. And noise pollution ranged between 66 and 79.7 decibels. Given the fact that 22 micrograms per metre cube of PM2.5 is equivalent to smoking one cigarette, a Chennaiite and pups have inhaled particulate matter equal to 31 cigarettes when PM2.5 was in 690-700 range. As per central pollution control board norms, AQI of 0-50 is considered good and 50-100 is satisfactory. Anything above 400 is severe. G Sundararajan of Poovulagin Nanbargal said the AQI which used to be in the range of 50-100 spiking beyond 700 on Diwali showed that crackers were one of the major polluters. "We request the state government to take a decision and implement a complete ban on crackers like the Delhi government," he said. It was not just the air pollution and noise pollution that were high. Even cracker waste went up by 70 tonnes compared to last year, as per Chennai corporation data, indicating that cracker indeed was the villain. At night, the TNPCB realtime monitoring stations showed PM levels of 950 ug/ m3 between 11pm and 12am in some locations which is disastrous for health. The TNPCB, however, claimed weather conditions also played a role. "This is due to large number of people bursting fi recrackers (mainly night crackers and sky shots) and high relative humidity and low wind speed. The climatic condition is not conducive for the effective dispersion of the smoke emanated from the bursting of crackers," the TNPCB statement read. The board had set up seven temporary monitoring stations for 15 days and monitored the pre-Diwali and post-Diwali levels of the air quality index For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Hero: G Sundararajan of Poovulagin Nanbargal

Title: Shamli directs farmers to send stubble to cow shelters
Body:
SHAMLI: As stubble burning is a primary factor for heavy air pollution in the Delhi and NCR region, the Shamli district administration is using a strict approach to prevent it. Besides, provision of free 15,000 bottles of bio-decomposers, farmers are advised to donate the bio waste after paddy harvest to cow shelters. "We have set a target to receive 600 tons of stubble waste to be deposited at cow shelters in the district and various methods of residue management are being taught to farmers through seminars," said DM Shamli Jasjeet Kaur. The district administration has warned that if any incident of stubble farming is found, FIR will be filed against the farmer and village Pradhan. Farmer leader Kapil Khatian told TOI, "We are facing the problem of fodder as crops have been affected due to late rain, straw has also decreased due to low yield of wheat. Thus, farmers will also use the leftover stubble as fodder. The government should take care of Delhi-NCR garbage dumps, prevent them from fire." For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Title: Air pollution worsening underlying diseases, it's a silent killer: Guleria
Body:
As Delhi breathes its toxic air, former AIIMS director Dr Randeep Guleria, who heads the department of pulmonary medicine and sleep disorders at the institute, tells Somrita Ghosh that pollution is a silent killer that is worsening underlying diseases. He rues the failure of government policies because of a flawed process of formulating them.How do you think the air pollution crisis in Delhi has impacted our lives? We are observing two things: one is the acute effect on the elderly and children - their hospital visits have gone up. I also know people who leave the city during this time for other parts of country, for instance southern India, because the air quality is better there. 
Data also shows that heart attacks go up during this time because of inflammation in the blood vessels caused by PM 2.5 and other ultrafine particulate matter.What long-term effects of this severe air pollution have you seen? Our studies have shown that on 70-80% of days - leaving that one year of Covid - the AQI has either been poor, very poor or severe. So, people living in the Indo-Gangetic plains are continuously breathing air which is of poor quality and that starts affecting their overall health. There are more chances of heart attacks and chronic respiratory problems. In children, it leads to retarded lung growth -- the lungs grow till age of 20, and if you are breathing bad air, then the lung capacity is not as much as it should be. Studies have shown that children growing up in Delhi have poor lung capacity compared to those growing up in southern India. There are studies which say that living in Delhi is a risk factor for heart diseases as much as for high cholesterol. Earlier, the focus was just on lungs and heart but now it has been proved that pollution particles go to the blood and travel to other parts of body; so strokes, dementia and other disorders are being reported.So, are we at a stage where we can directly link air pollution with mortality? Air pollution is a silent killer...other mortality factors can be examined but not pollution. Pollution causes worsening of underlying diseases. If you have a respiratory problem and are exposed to pollution, then respiratory issues worsen. It may also cause lung cancer and heart attack but the links have to be shown. Data is strong in terms of large studies but definite tests are not there. Lancet had said pollution was linked to death of 1.24 million people in 2017. What was interesting about that paper was that it showed that disability adjusted life years (DALY), especially in people with respiratory tract infection, stroke, heart disease and chronic respiratory problems, was affected even more by pollution than smoking. So, we need to develop strategies to deal with this. Otherwise, the burden of disease will continue to increase because of something which is preventable.A lot has been said about policies and measures to curb pollution over so many years but there has been no positive outcome. Why do you think these policies haven't succeeded? We need to develop a strategy for taking all stakeholders on board. We need a strategy for the targeted people -- What are their concerns? It could be socio-economic, regional or ethnic. Secondly, a sustainable solution should be worked out by looking at all sectors and understanding the issues the Indo-Gangetic plain has. It is a landlocked area and, therefore, whenever the air pollution is severe, the smog settles down at ground level. A lot is dependent on the weather in this region unlike in the coastal areas, and, therefore, we have to work aggressively on this. Also, a follow-up of the plans need to be done because if one plan is not working, we need to find alternatives.Do you think all the stakeholders were not considered earlier before making such policies? Policies have been made but somehow the implementation was not right, and we need to find out why. We are talking of crop burning for years and there have been so many solutions but farmers have not accepted them. So, what can we do? How can we incentivise it, so that the farmers get more profit from not burning the stubble? Then there is the whole issue of educating them.What do you think about the measures adopted by the Delhi government -- smog towers, water sprinklers, curbs on vehicle movement etc? We need to generate data to show that these measures are effective because some of them may not be effective. Whether a short-term or a long-term solution, there has to be an analysis to see if it is working, whether it is sustainable and economically viable. Only then should it be implemented. Or, one should move to other ideas. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Load-Date: November 9, 2022
Hero: former AIIMS director Dr. Randeep Guleria

Title: Jhansi: Premier agricultural research institute official booked for stubble burning on campus
Body:
JHANSI: Taking cognizance of the satellite images showing stubble burning inside the campus of Indian Grassland and Fodder Research Institute (IGFRI) - a national institute under the administrative control of Indian Council of Agricultural Research, the district administration has lodged a case against the farm in-charge of the institute on Saturday.According to details, it was observed through the satellite images that the farm residue was being burnt, which is otherwise banned in a large portion inside the campus of the prestigious research institute.Taking the matter seriously, the administration ordered officials to lodge a case against the responsible authority of the institute. Subsequently, an FIR was lodged at Sipri Bazar police station on the application of district agriculture officer KK Singh against the farm in-charge at IGFRI.Sipri Bazar station officer JP Pal said that a case has been lodged under different sections of IPC and Environment Protection Act 1986.Talking to TOI, IGFRI director Amresh Chandra regretted the act, saying that it was unknowingly done by the labourers. He, however, clarified that the residue which was burnt was not of crop, but of the fodder grown for the cattle.IGFRI is one of the premier research institutes under ICAR working on fodder crops for the farmers of Bundelkhand since 1962.Stubble burning has emerged as one of the major sources of air pollution in north India. 
According to estimates, about 23 million tonnes of paddy stubble are burnt annually by the farmers in northern India. Burning of stubble produces CO2, particulate matter, carbon monoxide, ash (black carbon) and SO2. In the recent years, it has become a major concern in Punjab, Haryana, Delhi-NCR and western Uttar Pradesh.Experts say stubble can be used in different ways like cattle feed, compost manure, roofing in rural areas, biomass energy, mushroom cultivation, packing materials, fuel, paper, bioethanol and industrial production. Title: Steady winds keep NCR air quality clean, pollution levels to fall further
Body:
Noida: The air quality of Noida and Ghaziabad remained in the 'moderate' category for the second consecutive day on Tuesday with the air quality index (AQI) being recorded at 136 and 159, respectively. The AQI in Greater Noida was recorded at 192. The System of Air Quality and Weather Forecasting and Research (SAFAR) said, "For the next three days, surface wind speed (8 to 16 km/h) and temperature (max 27-26 degrees C; min 8 degrees C) are likely to improve the AQI. The air quality is likely to remain within 'moderate' or 'lower end of poor' for the next three days due to moderate surface wind speed." 
A Noida Authority official said that they have been sprinkling water from STPs to mitigate the dust pollution. The Authority also tweeted photos of some tankers sprinkling water on roads in sectors 37, 38, 126, 135 and others. The minimum temperature recorded in Noida on Tuesday was 14.2 degrees Celsius and maximum was 26.1 degrees Celsius temperatures with fog in the morning. Ghaziabad recorded the minimum at 12.9 degrees Celsius and maximum 25.1 degrees Celsius temperatures. Meanwhile, Delhi's air quality improved remarkably and turned 'moderate' with a clean sky and cool north-westerly winds making it a soothing Tuesday.
The air quality index (AQI), on a scale of 0 to 500, was 177 as against 218 a day earlier and 306 on Sunday. This is the cleanest air the city has breathed since October 15 when the AQI was 186. This is also the cleanest December day in at least two years, as none of the days in December 2021 saw moderate air quality. On December 14, 2020, the AQI was 160.
According to pollution monitoring agencies, the air quality may improve further due to persistent winds and clear sky, which support ventilation of pollutants.
"The relatively stronger winds and better ventilation conditions are likely to prevail from December 13 to 15. The air quality is likely to improve further and remain in the moderate category on December 14. It may deteriorate marginally but remain in the same category on December 15. It will reach the poor category on December 16," stated the air quality early warning system.The maximum temperature hovered around 26 degrees Celsius, while the minimum temperature was recorded at 8.9 degrees Celsius.
For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Moral Description: Talks about how air quality is dependent on the weather

Title: NGT directs 100% waste processing in Hamirpur
Body:
SHIMLA: On the issue of violation of provisions of Air and Water Pollution Acts in Dughneri village of Hamirpur district in Himachal Pradesh, on account of the failure of authorities to handle the waste that is being burnt, causing air pollution, resulting in diseases, loss of livestock and contributing to forest fires and loss of wildlife, the National Green Tribunal (NGT) has directed the state to take further remedial measures expeditiously to accomplish 100% waste processing with zero legacy waste keeping in view the statutory timelines under the Solid Waste Management Rules, 2016. The NGT also said advancing the proposed timelines and compliance report of the status as on February 28, should be filed by March 15 and further directed the secretary (urban development) to oversee the remedial measures.Some local residents of Dughneri village had filed an application before the NGT against the violation of Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1981 and Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1974 in Dughneri and claimed that there is increase in population of monkeys, feral dogs and scavengers namely crows and vultures. They said the dump site in the hilly terrain is overflowing and contaminating the water body, which is a source of irrigation. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com

Title: CM Arvind Kejriwal's statements false, fabricated,twisted, says Delhi LG VK Saxena
Body:
NEW DELHI: In a stinging rebuttal to CM Arvind Kejriwal's statements at his press conference, LG V K Saxena has accused him of attributing to him "misleading, patently false and fabricated" statements."All statements attributed by the CM to the LG at his press conference after the meeting with regards to orders of the Supreme Court, powers as administrator, supremacy over all subjects and directions to officers are misleading, patently false and fabricated and twisted to suit a particular agenda. These statements are categorically denied," said the LG's office. Work for development of city, LG tells CMIn a rebuttal to CM Arvind Kejriwal's press conference, LG V K Saxena's office said, "The CM will also be well advised to function in accordance with the provisions of the Constitution, parliamentary acts and Supreme Court's judgments and refrain from running down an existing law just because it has been challenged in a court of law."Saxena said in a statement that he had taken up the issue of jurisdiction over certain subjects raised by the CM through various letters in the past few days and briefed him on his constitutional position and powers under various acts, statutes and court directions.The LG urged Kejriwal not to "politicise" every issue and asked him to work for the development of Delhi with "administrative effectiveness and fiscal prudence" in line with the Constitution.The AAP government, however, called the statement "malicious" and alleged that the LG's office had "cooked up" stories about things which were never discussed at the meeting. 
Raj Niwas said the LG reiterated at the meeting that he was "singularly bound by the Constitution" in discharge of his duties. "All his actions/decisions had been in conformity with the Constitution, acts of Parliament, statutes and judgments given by courts, from time to time," the statement read.Stressing that the well-being of people was the prime concern of both, the LG's office said Saxena deliberated with Kejriwal on various issues related to governance, administration and development of Delhi and flagged areas that needed attention. The statement added that "immoral" continuation of Satyendar Jain as a minister despite him being in prison for long was among the issues raised by the LG."Illegal appointment of private persons as government nominees on boards of private power distribution companies instead of government officers, despite written objections from two previous lieutenant governors, delay in projects of national and public importance, including redevelopment of AIIMS (and construction of) new academic blocks in IIT, expansion of Metro and NHAI works (and) corruption in government departments cropped up in the discussion," said the statement."Broken and potholed roads, air pollution and worsening condition of the Yamuna, no new hospital, school, college and flyover in the last eight years, encroachment of the river floodplains, worsened drainage system leading to severe waterlogging and no effort to clean the Najafgarh drain were other issues," it added.Raj Niwas added that the LG urged the CM to focus on the issues of the city and gave examples of the removal of over 40 lakh metric tonnes of garbage from three landfill sites and cleaning of more than 10km of the Najafgarh drain in just six months. "This was the result of the concerted efforts on part of various agencies, regular field visits and constant monitoring," the statement quoted the LG as telling Kejriwal at the meeting. The Delhi government, however, accused the LG of cooking up stories. "The LG's office has cooked up stories (on issues) that were never discussed at the meeting. It seems that the LG's office had already typed and prepared a dossier from its coloured lens before the meeting and was ready to share it with the media irrespective of what took place at the meeting," the government said in a statement."We strongly condemn such agenda-driven politics being played out in the name of a constitutional office. Raj Niwas must abstain from pointing guns at the elected government in such a manner. The LG has clearly been subverting the Constitution and the law of the land and it does not suit him to cook up stories to defend his obstructionist working," it added. For Reprint Rights: timescontent.com
